content:
, 2016
Original review (Improved and expanded review below)This game was so good in closed and open beta, my account is 4,5 years old created December 14, 2011 03:57, I figured I'd give the game a try again but wtf, it's just a empty shell, lackluster and just plain boring, I regret spending so much money on this game during closed beta and the beginning of open beta when it was still fun.I would suggest anyone to stay away from the game and instead play something like warframe, I don't play that anymore either, but I still do find myself coming back to that every now and then and don't feel so dissapointed when I do everytime.Please don't waste your time on this, the developers totally ruined this game.Edit:Just for the record, I've spend 200 euros on this game:Founder's Pack: Commander  Timestamp1/23/13 4:30am$100 USD ARES Starter Pack 7/11/13 1:56pm$100 USD That goes to show how great the game was, I was willing to spend that much money it was so much fun, but now it makes me sad that I have to tell people to stay away from the game, that it has become that bad compared to what it was.Edit2:Improved and expanded reviewI'll summarize the pro's and cons a bit and explain down further where necessary for anyone that hasn't played and wants a more indicative review for what to expect:Pros:+Very adjustable graphics+Great concept *1+Good balancing+Dynamic Environments+Generic enemy actually has background and lore+UI feels good, no clutter or anythingCons:-Community is spread out, same thing like in GW2, everybody is at the max lvl zones-Dynamic events get repetitive, you'll ignore them after some time-Game doesn't feel rewarding, you are grinding but you don't know for what *2-Game does very little to keep you playing, you will not feel engaged-Game has been washed out from the original concept, everything is very... lackluster *3-Not so well optimized, people still have issues on high-end machines*1 The concept of the game was great, the thing is, in closed and open beta you really felt the pressure of the enemy, you could see whole parts of the world fully under control of the Chosen, even the starter region was always under attack, I purely logged in everyday to check if we could save the day, it was so much fun liberating the entire map and then keeping it under control.You had Chosen squads patrolling in huge numbers and if you didn't stop them they'd take over control of areas, the game was remorseless it was hard on newbies because they wanted to apply the idea of everywhere is the metagame.It worked for a while, everyone could play with everyone and you could see who had been playing longer but it didn't matter cause they played together with the new people it was enticing, now it's just the same "This area is for lvl 1-10, that one for 11-20" etc and people don't give a ♥♥♥♥ about others anymore, it's basically what happend to WoW, before the burning crusade there was a real community, after that it became a mindless grind and everybody became a zombie with only their self-improvement in mind.*2In the beginning I the game was very rewarding, you could either grind the credits or xp and you'd get the items you want from the market that were crafted or buy a new suit, you were either saving up materials to craft parts yourself or one of the above and you would always set goals for yourself, if not then you'd play just for fun, because it was actually fun! Suprise huh?!Sometimes I'd just forgo progression to help random people thump dirt because we enjoyed defending thumpers in difficult areas or because they just needed xp and I happend to have the founder permanent bonus xp for parties applied to my account so I'd help them with their grind.*3Like I said in the previous comments, everything is washed out, the game lost it's focus on the original concept and just went for the mainstream to save it and like the others say, the company just doesn't care as much anymore about the player's opinions and thoughts as it used to, they REALLY tried to involve and informed us of everything in the beginning, that was part of why it was so great.So besides it getting washed out into just another generic mmofps the company behind it as well lost it's will to make it into something great, which is sadly sorely projected onto their game.Additional notes:I'd like to point out this video it's from June 2014: 


YouTube™ Video: Firefall - I Love Turret Mode 

			Views: 629		

			Firefall - I Love Turret Mode, and so should you! :) Subscribe to my channel for more: http://www.youtube.co/subscription_center?add_user=Nokzeen Follow me on twitter: https://twitter.com/nokzen1789...		

It goes to shows how many Chosen there were when they were taking outposts and this guy is decked out he can take them on but you can see has has to output massive dmg and he's still getting quite injured even when in turret mode, you just don't feel that powerful in the current state of the game, like the game doesn't give the you oppertunity and otherwise other people won't give a damn either.This is one of my own videos to display a bug cause I used to be active on the forums back then in October 2013: 


YouTube™ Video: Firefall thumper-nado bug 

			Views: 51		

			Nados aren't damaging thumpers anymore		

You can see I'm partied with Random people even though I had my own guild and we're just having fun playing for random events (We were nado hunting).I used to drop thumpers at every Nado during this bug just to add extra difficulty.I really miss those days.. :(And last but not least a video showcasing XP / Death valley which was the best fun I ever had in this game:


YouTube™ Video: Firefall XP FARMING?! 

			Views: 1,902		

			What do you guys think? Is this legitimate? Do you ever use death valley?		

Like he says, you'd just have 2 thumpers on either side of the valley and if it was primetime or you had some daring people there would also be 2 additional thumpers actually down in the alley, you'd have like 20-40 people of the 150 people on that whole server-node in that single valley, all blasting aliens to bits in chaos, it was amazing!

												The game is officially DEAD. It was awesome back in the day, but the company funding the devs didn't think that investing on new tools was good, so they made the devs work with 4 or 5 years old stuff to make the game work. And they did, for a bit, then they started to break things, they removed crafting, thumping, all the fun stuff was gone with the promise of making it better. Instead of doing it on a test server first they brought a broken version of the game to the live servers..and a couple of months later it officially died. I was dumb enough to pay 70 euros when they first launched, never again. It was open world, tons of missions, resource thumping, then defenending the thumpers while they farmed resources, random players walking by would join your thumper defense, sometimes the AI controlled enemies would attack a base, and if lost, that map zone would be locked, and to retake it you had to cooperate with other players, everything you needed from a shooter + rpg game was there. You had cars, bikes, you could use yuour jump jets to get on the highest mountain on the map and use your gliders to, glide, and see the entire map from the sky, it was fookin awesome, with those cartoonish graphics, but it was nice. It had tons of classes to choose from too, it's a shame that it died :(The bright side, a sucessor of Firefall is on the works, Ember. Fingers crossed!

14, 2016
												I've followed this game for years-- Ever since Engineers had a blowtorch instead of a grenade launcher.And lately, every patch has successively dumbed down the gameplay to the point that the game just isn't fun anymore.Try too hard to make your game appeal to the widest audience you can, and all you'll end up doing is falling into mediocrity. That is the literal definition of "pandering to the lowest common denominator".Don't try to please everyone-- You can't. Don't try to please the widest amount of people possible-- all you'll do is make something bland and uninspired.Don't try to copy a successful formula-- it's been done for so long that the industry itself is stagnating.This game had an incredible amount of potential. But the publishers threw the devs under the bus and crippled the game for the sake of making it more "marketable".This is a tragic loss.

content:
7, 2016
												Please note I played way more than 30 hours, I played during the closed beta for about 400 or so hours before it arrived on steam.What can I say that hasn't been said before. The game was probably one of the best MMO's I played in recent years. Well before they changed so many things that never needed to be changed. Things that made this game stand out amongst the plethora and constant releases of MMO’s. This was mostly due to Mark Kern being booted from being CEO, this is when the game started going downhill, and when some of the best and unique parts of the game being stripped down and removed. If that name sounds familiar, he worked as a team lead on some of Blizzards most popular titles. His stance on the current state of the game, in an interview via MMOBomb Originally posted by Mark Kern Via MMOBomb: pretty much a standard MMO now, instead of the simulated massive war game that I had always wanted to make”.  So it’s pretty much now your current run of the mill MMO.     Some of the best missions got removed, same with the lore, crafting was removed (which now has made thumping pretty much useless), frames being heavily restricted...and among other things. This sucked for many of the veterans that supported the game by buying the founders packs to support of what many of us thought was an amazing game (like my friends and I did after playing a long while), only to get screwed over in the long run by the new development path of the devs/new CEO. But to make this short, the game, which showed so much potential and promise, is pretty much dead now with almost no signs of changing and reverting back to what the veterans loved about it, and what made it unique. It got so bad that they were not able to pay their devs due to them not having the funds.   Though hope still remains since Mark said that if the game sees the sunset, then he’ll try and buy it back and save it, or if that doesn’t work (if he isn’t able to re-buy it), then he’ll make Ember, Firefalls spiritual successor. So there's hope that we will still see some version of Firefall in the near future. If you want to play it, I say it's worth a look, but I wouldn't invest any money into it, since it does appear to be failing. http://www.mmobomb.com/features/mark-kern-firefall-different-early-id-re-purchase-became-available/ -  His quote on the current state . Also may be a reason why he was removed. (though they come from employees that were under his leadership)  http://www.mmobomb.com/news/mark-kern-launches-petition-ember-firefalls-spiritual-successor/ - Some extra info on his new game if he can’t get Firefall   *Edit - Guess Steam hates MMOBomb.  *Update/Edit #2 - That Ember thing I mentioned, it appears it now has a forum https://forums.emberthegame.com/   If the link doesn't work (or Steam removes it), then just type in "Ember the game" in Google. GLHF, and I hope to so you nomads on the new frontier!

content:
, 2015
												When I first heard about Firefall, it was right about the time it went to OBT. The first few hours of gameplay was confusing as hell, because there was no tutorial for crafting, resource gathering, no information about the story etc. Yet, I dug myself into the game. I wanted to learn it. I poured in it around 200~ hours in open beta. After I understood the mechanics, I was simply sucked in into this world.It was a sci-fi shooter, with a moderately deep, but quite hard-to-learn crafting/leveling/gathering system. The idea, that  - a player had the choice to thump (mine) 4x4 different kind of materials - which each had a quality system from 0 to 1000 - while you had the option to explore the whole map to get the highest quality for your gear - keeping low quality for the "level-ups", which was kinda like the talent-system in vanilla WoW - and depending on the quality and property of the material, freely modify what you are about to buildwas fascinating. It was hard. There were grindy parts, but the whole game felt like a big cooperation between palyers. Unfortunately the story was progressing very slowy, and the content was quite shallow, while the crafting system was a b*tchslap to all those players, who thought this will be an easy game. Half year before the game came out, I took a brake from it. Then it came out, I logged in, and my heart was broken...They simplified it to the extent, that even WoW is better now in 90% of its aspects. Unless you would like to shoot-'n'-grind a few hours, this game is not for you.Until they give back the OBT crafting/thumping/leveling system, this game is a no-go for me.

number of helpful: 79 of 108 people (73%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
ber 21, 2014
												This game will trick you into thinking it's good, while it actually is horrible. By that, I mean there are a lot of almost saving graces. The gameplay is fun, the way frames are made to do something wildly different than most other frames is well done. But that's about where the good parts end. I let my hope get the best of me, and continued playing this and progressed quite far, so I've seen everything the game has to offer at this point, as far as actual content. I have 3 frames yet to unlock, but I think they'll probably remain locked forever, because I'm uninstalling. Let me tell you just a few of the completely broken things in this game. 1) Bugs. This game is filled with bugs, left and right. At time of writing, I cannot login, because the login servers are down- DURING A 4 HOUR LONG EVENT. Which leaves innumerable players (including myself) unable to get the rewards from said event. I wish I hadn't logged out, because I'd at least earned credit for the event. But I figured that since my screen was frozen for up to two minutes at a time (Not a problem on my end; CPU, ram, gfx card all WELL within tolerances) I might restart my computer and see if that helped. Turns out, I can't login at all now. That's just one of countless bugs which plague this game from start to finish. 2) The game is a grindfest. You can't play ONE frame. I mean sure, you get to level 40 with your first frame, "Yay now I can do the 3 endgame raids there are!" Yeah but not well. The thing is that to get the right perks to make your frame actually decent, you need to level up other frames. Some as high as 40, some only to 10, 20, or 30. Regardless, if you want to maximize your play experience, prepare to spend hundreds of hours grinding. This grindfest brings me to....3) The crafting system. Which is even more of a joke. For one level 40 epic item, the time spent grinding the same thumper in the same zone is maddening. Not to mention the fact that it's not just one zone you'll have to do it in, it's usually two or sometimes all three zones, for different items. 1200 uranium bars, AKA 6000 uranium ore, when you've got a chance at around 100 uranium ore average from a 5 minute long thump. That's for ONE of the materials involved. Bone fragments are much harder to come by, but required in similar numbers. Oh but you can just buy it off the market instead, right?? Lol, sure, if you feel like....4) MORE GRINDING FOR FREAKING CREDITS. Yup, the main source of credits being injected into the economy, comes from farming crystite(Warfront will get you 15-25k per hour, or would before they nerfed the drop rates). You can convert 25k crystite into 1k credits every day, and you can easily farm 25k crystite in about 1-2 hours, per day, at level 40. But 40 epic abilities? 20-40k credits. 40 epic core? 50-80k credits. So if you wanted to get those credits from just farming crystite, it would be close to a year before you could buy what you wanted to. Luckily, there are other options for gaining credits, it doesn't have to take that long. You could.... grind another frame to 40 and sell the mods from getting level 40. Or you could... grind world mobs on a thumper in hopes of an epic drop that you can sell for the credits to buy an ability for your frame. Have I made the point clear about this game being one long grindfest from start to finish? 5) The content is mediocre at best. There's really a very limited variety in what works in the game. Yes, all the frames work quite differently. On a spectrum from "LOL you're playing THAT frame? /kick" to "Nerf Raptors." I wish I were kidding, but that's how it goes. This is partially mitigated by the fact that all players can play all frames. At 10k +- 3k credits each, or buying them for real money/red beans. But again, if you want to be able to solo thump, and do bane/kana, and do warfront, you're going to need at least 3 frames at 40, probably 4, and if you want them to be perked properly, you're looking at 8-10 frames at level 20-30 or higher, some more frames you won't use at 40, but you have to level just for a perk. 6) PVP is a joke. Broken Peninsula is just that. Broken. The frame imbalances are so severe that if you don't use one of the currently OP frames, you're going to die constantly. Raptor, Rhino, Recluse, maybe a nighthawk, otherwise, get ready to eat lead salad all day long. 7) Devs are very heavy with the nerfbat in areas that don't need it. Especially droprates, which they've nerfed time and again during my time playing. I'm just glad I farmed BWA while it was possible to get more than a single green. They went from a guaranteed two blue "necro" weapons, plus the chance at a green/blue mod or the warpaint, to ONE drop. It might be a green weapon. It might be the warpaint. But you get ONE. Did I mention they reduced the loot, at the same time they made the instance take about twice as long as before? Nerfiest Nerf I ever nerfed. It's not so much harder, as you're not allowed to skip mobs that you could skip before. Other times, they seem to forget the nerfbat exists, like raptors, which are currently the most overpowered frame for just about every situation. Or recluses, which simply gets better the more enemies you throw at it. At some point, the recluse turns immortal, simply because of the fact it is amazing AOE damage, and gets 10% of it's damage as heals. It is just... imbalanced isn't strong enough to describe the way that the frames work. I dedicated a lot more hours to this game than is reported by Steam, simply because I don't always launch the game through steam. I've played a LOT. And honestly. I wish this game was better. But for all the potential it has, I've seen it going downhill fast during the time I've played. I highly recommend not even installing this game. The gems it has are very visible, and it's easy to get hooked, and then gloss over the "minor inconveniences." But the inconveniences pile up, and when they add something new... be prepared for a crashfest. I personally showed a developer a bug in warfront, soon after it was released. It was one of at least 4 MAJOR and I mean game changing bugs. This particular bug was the difference between a 6 minute objective, and hitting the timer at 20 minutes and everyone dying, and having to wait the 2:30 to attempt the whole objective over again. Which I still don't consider as bad as the bug where the entire raid's game crashes. Both of which took WEEKS to fix (if they even are fixed, they weren't consistent bugs). I've been addicted to hope in this game for too long. The current staff responsible for the direction the game is heading, and the actual game itself, are incompetent. This game is going downhill fast, and I strongly recommend you stay away from it, unless you like reporting bugs constantly in a game which is *supposed to be* released. I can't stay addicted to hope. For all the good things in it, this game is just bad.

content:
0, 2014
												Firefall has a personality disorder. Its centerpiece is supposedly a world war between a besieged humanity and a superior alien civilization, but players spend most of the time roaming around engaging random clumps of indigenous bandits, mining for resources, and killing mutated fauna. There is a lack of sense about the relevancy or urgency of the war.Leveling mechanics, itemization, crafting, and questing systems are conventional and unremarkable. Narratives conveyed in missions are discontinuous, because the missions themselves are randomly sequenced. The encounter system is simplistic: most scenarios reduce to close-range engagements as enemies materialize into existence near you. Enemy AI is mediocre: No squad tactics, no flanking, no suppression, no cover. Combat is mostly reduced to jumping and backpedaling away from enemies. It becomes less about surviving enemies, and more about surviving the point-blank splash damage from your own weapons.Play it for the eye candy and esthetics, and for the easy adrenaline. Look elsewhere for more filling and better execution. Intelligently challenging PVE battles, cohesive narratives, and a world story that invites urgency elude Firefall at this time.

content:
, 2016
												tl;dr- If you haven't played this game before, do so right now-- while there's still a game left to play. But if you're a veteran like I am, playing this game again will just get you thinking about the "Good ol' days". At least it did for me.I really wanted to be able to give this game a positive review. I wanted it more than anything else in the world. It has so many good memories for me, and when I first played in the summer of 2013 near the end of the closed beta, I remember thinking that it the most fresh and innovative MMO that I had seen in a long time. (Granted, I'm sort of an antisocial person, so I tend to hate MMOs because I don't play too well with others.) But since I picked it back up a few weeks ago, I can only say that things have gotten worse since I last played, which was about a month after the Sertao patch first went live.Even then, I thought FireFall was going down a negative slope-- but back then I thought it was either just a fluke that would be fixed in the next few patches, or because I had simply burned myself out by playing it too much. But now it's become clear that Red5 has fallen so far that they can't recover. Especially after the buyout by the Chinese company "The Nine", (Which sounds like the name of a terrorist faction in a cyberpunk movie, by the way.) and when you take the time to consider that the members of Red5 that recieved the money basically immediately blew it all on hats. It kinda shows how little respect and care they had left for their own game near the end.As for the quality of gameplay, like I said before, it's been on a negative slope for a while, but I only just noticed how steep the slope was. The open world experience overall used to be much better. There wasn't a set level barrier between areas or even strict "levels" at all. The whole world was open to anyone at any power level, and you could proceed and explore at your own pace. If you ♥♥♥♥ed up and went somewhere too strong for you, that was your own mistake. Now the zones (Coral Forest, Sertao and Diamond Head) have fallen back into the classic MMO mistake of being segmented and cordoned off into areas with seperate level requirements. It really cockblocks the fun factor of exploring this game and forces you back into grinding in one spot until you're strong enough to move on rather than growing through exploration. Back in MY day, anyone could go to Sunken Harbor any time they wanted, but now it's a level 30+ zone.The quality of the quests has seen a sharp decrease as well. Except it's not even consitent. The old ARES missions that have been here since the summer of 2013, and even the first 25% of the main questline are still pretty fun and well designed. The remaining 75% of the main quest and the new open world missions, however... Well, it's obvious where Red 5 dropped off and The Nine picked up. Even based off of voice acting quality alone and ignoring the rest of the missions. The bad voice acting was funny for about 15 minutes but then it made me die a little bit inside after I realized why. That being said, the new "missions" are also horribly broken and glitchy. Overpowered bosses, convoluted objectives that could just be replaced with something so simple as a door key, et cetera. I was having troubles defeating a level 20 boss in my level 45 armor because of how broken he was. I've also heard complaints from guildmates (who are also veterans in maxed out armors) about the exact same mission near the end of the questline (which I have failed to make it to because of a game breaking bug earlier in the campaign). The9, convolutedness isn't a substitute for balanced difficulty at higher levels. Like I said, I wish that I could have given this a good review. I really wanted to. Despite its greatly increasing flaws, this game is still very unique, especially in the F2P MMO scene. With its true 3D movement mechanic and diversity between classes, FireFall's potential was immense. But now when I look it all I see is what could have been and what soon won't be. One of my favorite games is circling the drain, and it's breaking my heart.

content:
8, 2014
												Review and tips focused towards new players, i am a beta player with over 2 years test experience in this title.----First off, you need to know that this 3rd person shooter is also a MMO experience, so keep in mind you need to grind levels and components, a lot of time is needed to play this game, and with how the system works (and a good point i might add) is that you cant just sit there and leech from other people, you physically need to participate to gain XP and credit. So be prepared for a long-lasting (but awesome) experience so long as youre someone who enjoys actually playing the game and not just ya know..sat leeching from someone or not giving a crap.***Gameplay: 7 / 10The content is good, the single player missions are good, the different variations of World events and randomly generated content work great! The only problem is, there's not enough different types of mission and it can quickly become repetetive, which goes the same for story missions, theyre enjoyable but there just isnt enough of them (yet). I highly recommend playing with friends especially if they can give you a ride, or (i highly advise) you puchase with Red Beans of ingame Credits, a BIKE. Without a vehicle this game is a looong walk simulator, but as soon as you get a vehicle and craft yourself a lot of 1-use glider pads this mobility problem goes away (it sorta forces you to get a vehicle, but thats ok they need to make money somehow to sustain these big servers).PvE Content is very well balanced and challenging, if you charge into a base full of bandits or chosen at your level, expect to get yourself killed very quickly as especially the Chosen, are a force to be reconned with. PvP is promising but ultimately, there's no balance and its only fun for the few. The classes you are allowed to play cover all the basic roles (tank, support, healer, dps etc) and the advanced battleframes (which i recommend Bastion, Dragonfly/Recluse, Raptor/Nighthawk or Mammoth for new players as these currently seem the most powerful) grant even further power to your class.They have confirmed, and are adding a lot of content in the future including a level cap rise with (confirmed) at least 2 new world-zones, so expect a LOT of good things for this free-to-play title.***Sound: 7 / 10The music feels very gripping with its orchestral quality and all weapons sounds great, you really feel the oomph of your weaponry and explosions from afar you can almost feel the vibrations from. Sound quality is excellent! Though the roaming music can sorta make you a bit sleepy. The musical score is wonderful in missions and cutscenes but the roaming music is too boring. The game's vocal content and all NPC's (and quest givers) is about 97% fully voice acted! Some of those accents though are not very well spoken, and may sounds a bit cheesy, several of the voice actors seem uninterested but overall, sound is good.***Graphics and worlds: 5 / 10 The maps look average and the systems overal graphics are well toned (character style inspired from Street Fighter 4). I wouldnt call firefall next-gen, its sorta in between last gen and next gen. It's optimized enough to run smoothly including in huge fights of 40 players and a hundred enemies at once on the screen (which is amaaaaziiiiing) but GPU Temperatures can run a little high so i highly recommend turning a few things down (shadows low or off, and antialiasing off unless your computer is an icecube). The worlds although they looks pretty, (gunna be honest here) will p### you off, as every obstacle, every mountain with no climbable surface, every tree/rock/nook and granny and just how lumpy the ground is, seems to do its utmost best to slow you down and hinder your ability to go someplace, which is why they sell glider-pads in game to make money off of you. Because of the terrible pathing in maps and how it fights and pushes you to the point of frustration when youre trying to be in a rush to go someplace, it heavily impacts this rating. The maps by design are agonizing.***Overall: 7 / 10There's a lot of potential here, keep in mind you DO have to spend some money if you want to get anywhere near end-game here because of long distance traveling and the advanced battleframes being stronger (mostly), but with the extra content coming, the community being really supportive of Firefall, and the playerbase being really co-operative and nice in game, i highly recommend this title.Remember, it's free-to-play, but if you want to get serious about this game, you will need to spend a little money OR, spend a lot of time. Recommended: Get a vehicle, unlock the class you really want to play, tryout a 100% XP boost to get out of the first 10 boring levels and BOOM! You got yourself a really fun game, with great PvE experiences, and a solid future.

number of helpful: 171 of 275 people (62%) found this review helpful42 people found this review funny
content:
11, 2015
												WARNING: This is an outdated review, I don't plan on going back to Firefall and relearn the whole damn thing so there are no plans currently to rewrite this entire review. Enjoy my rant.Ah Firefall, one of the few MMO's out there who have shown promise and does it's best to live up to it while other games   cough cough!* Destiny cough cough!   have failed to deliver and as a result developers (and publishers included) over hype it's content.Now you may ask: "why Firefall? surely there are better MMOs out there!" no, there really aren't. I have played Rift, SWTOR, WoW, Warframe, Runescape the list goes on and none of those MMOs have impressed me in the least. SWTOR is basically WoW with a Star wars coat of paint plagued by EA's greed and Bioware's massive ego. Rift, was 'okay' but it's still WoW with a new skin and nothing more. Warframe was 90% of the time a Dungeon raid grinding simulator plagued by microtransactions and slow progression all set to make more money, and while I am aware the devs must make money to continue development of said game sometimes it can get out of hand. And finally WoW, their business model is a dying animal from 1999 dragged into this modern world hoping for customers. And while WoW is addictive it's community is toxic as hell. If you don't know what I'm talking about I suggest looking up some of the role play. Now what exactly makes Firefall different from all the rest? Firefall is a F2P FPS/TPS/MMO with of course, jetpacks. It's setting is in the future so it's a sci-fi MMO and that all together is all the reason you need to play it. Why you might ask? because every other MMO out there is trying to be the same thing which is pretty much Dungeons and Dragons. This is a fresh breath of air within the MMO side of gaming that should be explored further, but everyone seems to be quite stupid so let them rot with their WoW clones.But this isn't enough information for you to play the game and try it out for yourself. I am explaining this from my opinion, what I should really be doing is giving you the good sides and the bad sides of this game instead of hitting on other games for their lack of creativity. Gameplay:  While Firefall's combat may not hang on button mashing a spell in multiple slots, the combat is no where near perfect. The combat is a little glitchy and tends to be awkward when fighting NPC's due to NPC's "skiing" around with poor animation quality. Which is yet another problem with the combat, the animations need desperate work because it makes indie zombie survival game combat look as fluid as clear water (although it isn't really that bad, but close enough.) First person perspective's animations are just as bad because the view model seems to break quite often either by random chance or exiting large frame drops, so for the most part you'll be playing in Third person. Now don't get me wrong the combat is fun enough to continue playing, but it needs help if it wishes to keep shooter fans such as myself invested.And now for the meat of the game, grinding! because that's fun right!? doing missions over and over and over and over until you get to the next level so you can go to the higher level area and do missions there over and over and over and over again it's so much fun I muted the game! Why?! why do dev's think an MMO's primary goal is to drive yourself insane? I don't want to do the same things I did with the last class until I get my next class to 40! Can you guess what you get in return for grinding all the way up to 40?  *plays drumb roll*  if you guessed more grinding then you. are. the WINNNNNNAAAAAH!!! you get to go play Warzones in Devil's Tusk with other overly powerful level 40 players and get boat loads of XP you can't use! But wait! there's more! if you didn't think tedious resource gathering was enough for you, now you can go do tedious resource gathering as enemy players eat your limbs off in seconds while watching them ♥♥♥♥ your family in front of you crying tears of blood! FUN RIGHT?!Here's a better idea, make the end game worth it. You tortured people all that way just to give them the same thing they were doing at the lower levels but this time far, far, worse! Let's say for example: at the end game you can now get four player special ops missions that require certain skill types such as stealth, distraction, stealing, etc and in return you can get cosmetics or higher chances of getting purple items- something atleast worth leveling to 40. Because I couldn't give a damn about how powerful my character is when all you have to do is stay in the air and fire down death until you complete X Y and Z objectives. Plus mobs can't complain on a forum about how over powered you are so I really can't care about my strength unless fighting in PVP which pretty much boils down to who has the most purple gear anyway... Storyline:  Ooooooooh boy, I am not going to have fun explaining this. I'll get straight to the point and say it's a poorly written saturday morning cartoon show. The writing is so tasteless it makes me want to dry heave!  Everything  is predictable! for example: "jee, I hope giant crabs from space don't rain on us" *giant crabs from space rain on you* "oh no this was so unpredictable your  armor's power is draining and now you can't fly because reasons...Oh dear, let me bring them back up as slowly as I can." And they do nothing to mix it up. Whatever you do when you play this game, avoid job boards unless you are an achievement hunter.The good news is the story can be ignored, the bad news is no one cared enough to make a compelling cast of characters. Yeah, you have your hot hacker chick telling you what to do and a redneck uncle engineer to add as comedy relief but at the end of the day you have no reason to care for these people. Yeah I get it, I'm not expected to care for the virtual characters, but for the sake of the player, at least make them half decent. The plus side however, most MMOs don't have voice acting at all. Of course games like WoW have shop dialogue "oy! come to sell yer ♥♥♥♥ son?" "I buy and sell ♥♥♥♥" "hurry up on over here so I can buy your ♥♥♥♥" "I sell quality ♥♥♥♥ at the ♥♥♥♥♥iest price!" But the majority of it is text, it's not like I hate reading but when the entire game has a weak plot and a crappy UI I have already lost interest at level 1. So Red5 get's points for placing honest effort into it. Final Verdict  So what are the good things I can say about this game? well it's free, you can unlock everything within the game for free if you are willing to work for it, and it has a great community as well as developers. But the glitches and the lack of content is what holds me back from speaking positively about this game. It's not like I didn't try to like this game! I really wanted to enjoy Firefall, and I still do, but it's a love/hate relationship. I have 322 hours on record as proof that I enjoyed the game enough to soldier through it's flaws and eventually write a review on it. And in return I give Firefall a 6/10, it's above 5 because it is trying to be a good MMO that doesn't constantly try to harpoon your wallet every chance it gets like most MMO's I have played. Now do I suggest you install FF right now? well, the in game music is broken, the UI is always glitching (it can even go as far as restarting your game) and this cannot be fixed via hotfix. Despite that go ahead and install it if you have the space for it otherwise move along.

content:
2016
												Don't bother. This game has been reworked about four times now. Even after kicking that idiot Mark Kern to the curb, development still has absolutely no direction whatsoever.Most of the balance changes are actually decent. However, this latest update disabled a lot of features because suprise, they're being reworked. For the fifth time. Also, end game zones? Being reworked as well, so good luck finding stuff to do at max level, especially since thumping is no longer fun in the slightest.For those who played before, remember the arsenal frame? It had pretty decent firepower with its LMG, and abilities granted weapons with limited ammo to be used in certain situations. A shotgun with high damage, a particle beam for long range AOE, and so on. Its ultimate was great, my favorite one in the game. Ever see Macross? The mechs which could fire off a ton of missiles at once? Basically that, though the rockets here arc like mortar fire. And it was AWESOME!Sounds like a cool frame, right? Well, it's gone. Just removed completely because the developers are too stupid to figure out how to bolster its shortcomings. And not one single frack was given when people who loved it clamored for it back. They did offer pretty nice compensation, but as cool as the vehicle is, I'd rather have my Arsenal back. Save your time and energy for something else. This game could have been wonderful, but they spent far too much time just figuring out what they wanted this game to be... and still are! If you must try, I'd recommend not spending any real money. Let's face it, the game and Red5 are on its last legs. I'm actually surprised it's lasted this long, especially after its abysmal failure in Asia. I really don't think they'll make it to the end of 2016. Need to get your shooter fix? There are plenty of better offerings on Steam. Go try one of those, and leave this game to die. BTW my play time was mostly using the proprietary launcher, not Steam. So ♥♥♥♥ off with hours played BS.

content:
8, 2014
												Let's start with the bad since that's probably the first thing many people will notice before they can adequately give it a chance:  this game is a buggy mess.  At one point in my first week of playing the social network went down for about an hour or so, so there were no squads, no local chats, no zone chats, no private chats.  That was...interesting for an MMO.  Also count in the sheer amount of times youll have to /rui or simply relog on the game and it's easy to see more than a few problems with this "new" release.  One other thing I wasn't particularly impressed with was the voice acting.  Some of the higher 'brass' sounds like little more than some doughboy CS developer-type guy.  Some of the voice acting simply sounds LAZY, where you expect the person you're reporting to to at least SOUND like he/she commands some sort of air of authority.  Additionally, more than a few of the accents sound forced.  OK so fair enough, this game didn't cost me anything to download but spacetime.  Despite the issues, this game has a LOT of redeeming qualities and so now we'll move on to why I recommend it.  While the level cap is low for an MMO (currently only 40; I've gotten a little more than halfway there at this point in time), Red 5 offers within Firefall a world lush with touristic scenery (the first town, Copacabana, is similar to an island vacation destination), Borderlands-esque graphics (cell-shading) and gameplay, and random bad guys including oversized bugs (giving it a Starship Troopers kind of feel at times), various rebel factions, and a cult of sorts that goes by the name of the Chosen.  In this world, the "Melding" has descended after a massive semi-apocalyptic event called the "Firefall", spawning the Chosen and as an ARES mercenary it's your inevitable destiny to push this purple tyranny back into the shadowy depths from which it came.  As someone who just hit their 20's in game, I don't know if there's ever an overall resolution towards this problem but I'm sure having a good time getting to that end point.As you level up, there are several towns for almost every level range so location diversity is never really a problem.  Each of these towns has it's own job board which supplies you with a set of level appropriate gopher/defense missions to help you level.  There's also a main string of campaign quests that you steadily unlock as you level up that add to the story of the war against the Melding.  In some of these missions you actually push the melding back by activating a SIN Uplink in the area (so THAT's what those are for!). In your time spent playing Firefall, there are several other things to do if you don't like the mainstream find/grind missions.  Several random missions occur in your local area, ranging from melding tornados (around level 15-20 it seems are the lowest ones you can find) that you have to spend some time shooting down to random LGVs and Thumpers crashing down in your area which you can save for a decent chunk of xp and resources.  Sometimes Chosen dropships like to pay visits to SIN Uplinks in towns or at watchtowers and attack/take them over, after which it's team ARES' responsibility to liberate and take back the area.Using Thumpers in itself is another gem of this game's overall existence.  Yet another choice while exploring the world is to scout out mineral nodes that randomly spawn throughout.  Find a node, call down your thumper, and prepare to defend it for the next 5 minutes while it mines resources for you and bugs are trying to destroy it.  A successful thump gets you xp and resources based on the % of the minerals present in the area you're thumping.  An unsuccessful thump sees your thumper destroyed, but that's OK!  You can just craft another one!Crafting is one area of the game that seems a bit overwhelming at first, but it actually ends up fitting into the game quite nicely for those higher teens and lvl 20+ areas.  Almost everything you pick up is salvagable, which gets you research points, crystals, and refinable materials that can later be used in crafting.Mobility EARLY game is KIND of an issue, but not really.  For the most part you'll be walking around everywhere until level 25 when you get a reusable ground vehicle, but there are some alternatives.  1-use ground vehicles drop from quests and I believe they're also craftable if you so desire.  In addition to the possibility of ground vehicles you have the entire hang gliding system which is it's own source of entertainment, not to mention a much quicker way to get places.  I especially enjoy climbing the highest mountains (there are achievements for climbing these mountains as a matter of fact) and spawning a glider pad to fly off of them.  Some of these mountains literally make it possible to fly clear across a region from one side to the other, just don't fly near the Arclight! :DAs far as replayability is concerned, you don't have to ever create a new character if you don't want to.  All the different classes are separated by what are known as "battleframes" in game, which one can change not unlike a shirt or some other equippable article of clothing.  Now, each time you equip a new frame you haven't played before it starts at level 1 but all the early missions are replayable for xp/resource credit.  I should also mention that starting out as a free player you only get access to the  5 different accord frames, which are the basic frames in each of the 5 different battle classes.  Here's the beauty of this particular free2play game, though:  you don't ever have to spend a dime of your real money in game to get everything there is to get, it might just take a while longer.  There is always the option of buying stuff for those that are impatient and want to try out some of the elite frames sooner rather than later, like me.  Bought Electron and Bastion on the first night.All-in-all, I do recommend this game.  It has a lot of potential.  It's very engaging; the gameplay is moderately-paced and 3-dimensional based in a wide-open world.  Listening to the soundtrack is often pretty relaxing.  This game also does have PvP, though I've spent next to no time exploring that particular venue cause there's so much other fun stuff to do in PvE that, quite refreshingly, doesn't seem so repetitive.  Even the campaign missions you unlock changes up the scenery and the objective in each one so it's not simply a generic mission formula.  It's obvious they took some time to plan the campaign missions out.  Now if only they'd spend the time to make sure that some of my local town job quests didn't get stuck loading the next objective or that I'm at least ALWAYS able to invite my friends to quest with me in a squad (I will not forget that ONE experience, but to any potential players reading this, it was just the ONCE).  Try this game if you like F/TPS, cooperative gameplay, and a decent story line.

number of helpful: 214 of 355 people (60%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
4, 2014
													A study in game design theory, Firefall is a title that is fantastic on paper and mediocre in practice.  Most of what's present is forgivable, but the primary attraction is ultimately its biggest liablity.  Ultimately, it won't appeal to MMO fans due to it's watered down questing and pve mechanics, and action fans will dismiss it due to a lack of refinement.  	Firefall's story revolves around the discovery of meterological elements that allow us to build fantastic technology, such as jet pack suits, advanced weapons, and space ships.  The goal of traveling to an Earth like planet is foiled by further plot mechanics, as the ship crashes into Earth, rendering most of the surface uninhabitable.  The obligitory aggressive alien species comes to Earth to take over, and this sets the stage for blah blah blah.   	Poorly written sci fi tropes doesn't compel a player to continue on with the story, so the game heavily relies on the action elements.  These are where the biggest problems manifest, because the actual meat of the game is mediocre at best.  The game has a one to one action component, which is unusual for MMO's as it's a genre that caters to point and click, but Firefall tries desperately to stand out.  Instead it feels like a mechanically stripped down shooter with very little to differentiate itself from the hundreds of other FPS games, and strapping a jet pack to your character does very little to help.  	The actual physics of flying feel so static and boring that it really shouldn't have bothered.  Instead of using it as a method to travel quickly from place to place, it simply allows for altitude adjustments, and has very little “skiing”, something that the tribes games were lauded for.  Strategically, it's still important for melee centric enemies as you'll jet above them and shoot as they attempt with great futility to nibble your ankles.  If an inertial effect was added to the jetting the game would be a pleasure, especially with the varied terrain.  As is, moving from point A to B in the game is a chore.	Production values crush what enjoyment could have been gleaned from the rest of this game, as the graphics, sound, interface, and general design are adequate, but that's it.  The view distance for terrain, monsters and allies is good, but up close they look pretty meh.  This is in no small part due to an unusual cartoonish design, somewhere between Borderlands and World of Warcraft, but nowhere near as endearing as either.  It comes off as generic and unexciting, with little if anything unique about it.  Enemy design suffers the most, as it isn't just dull, it only has a handful of variations.  In about 3 hours of gameplay, I had seen the same arachnid design used for about half the enemies, and zombie like enemy soldier for the other.  From the sound of a machine gun to rockets firing, to my commander speaking to the lowly civilians, everything sounds awful.  The voice acting especially is cringe worthy, with the theater commander taking the prize for most obnoxious line delivery this year.  	Potential is squandered on a regular basis in the gaming industry, but rarely had expectations been so high; a 1 to 1 action mmo with jetpacks, a pvp component, and a free to play model.  All that's left is an excellent case study in how design doesn't necessarily equate to execution.  Firefall isn't terrible, it's just a really basic, stripped down action game that just happens to have an MMO component tacked on.  Both are incredibly basic and unrefined, and leaves very little to entice fans of either genre.  In the end, it really isn't worth your time unless major improvements are made.

content:
er 17, 2014
												This is going to be a short and to the point review, so forgive the lack of flattery or filler.This game has been holding onto life by some force I don't even recognize, to be honest.I played this game back in closed beta and it was amazing and new to me. Given it didn't have much content, but it was always updating and the story was opening up. I would've given the game a 7.5/10 score.It's been a long time now and I have played a good chunk of time again, and I am sorely disappointed.* It's full of bugs and glitches that aren't typically fixed. Some are, most are not.* Updates don't always fix what's broken and they include what the community has called 'Ninja Updates' that they intentionally hide so as to try and avoid confrontation from their playerbase.* A game once made to reward skill and strategy is now just "Who can do the more AoE damage". Skill is no longer a thing. The deadliest and most used classes are AoE classes, aside from Dragonfly healers of course.* PvP is more or less dead. Now the PvP zone sees only the occasional battle but is more or less quiet and only for getting materials.* The game is horribly optimized. Beefy computers can see lag. Amazing connections will still see latency problems.* The phrase "Don't fix what isn't broken" is often seen in action.* Most of the crafting in the game is worthless. You can skip over it till endgame and not suffer for it much at all.* Just to keep up with most of the playerbase, you have to play for weeks to get daily rewards just to get VIP status to earn enough in-game currency to do anything.I tried to enjoy the game and even joined an army (guild, clan, whatever you wanna call it) and ran around with them but it was already too late. I had seen the game poisoned for me beyond repair.Now I rate this game 3/10. It's a waste of time.As far as I am concerned, the only reason this game is still alive is because they have something that hasn't been done better yet. If someone came up with a game similar to this and actually did it justice, I would probably be all over it and I doubt there wouldn't be masses of players wanting in on it too.TL;DR - This game isn't worth the headache, the time sink or the urge to pay into the game just to get a leg-up. Skip it over and wait for something better.

content:
4, 2016
Don't let the birds get me.I'm primarily a traditional MMO player, so I was really surprised that this FPS-heavy one where everyone has battleframes caught my attention. I'm not really a fan of mecha, either. But for maybe the first 700 hours I played the game, it was great. I played mostly assault-style frames like the Tigerclaw, where the whole point of the frame was to be nimble and jump around the field a lot, with an afterburner letting you stay in the air for a long period of time. This was also key to managing a lot of the terrain easily. But after the last major patch and subsequent fixes, I can't stay in the air more than a few seconds. I can't do all my terrain tricks any more. I can't even use my vehicles the same way. And this is all intentional. Even if I could, a lot of the old storylines have changed. Sure, the scenery looks better in places. Certainly busier, at least. But the heart's gone out of it, I think.Within the game, there used to be a hidden crayon drawing, taped up behind a bookcase, from a kid who was the admiral's son. Just one of the billions of people who died in the initial tragedy, but someone whose death we knew about. It was just a small thing that most people never saw, but for me it made everything and everyone we lost personal, and served as a reminder why we shouldn't give in and let the Melding and oblivion overtake us. But, like so many other things, that's apparently been lost or moved. And dim memories of the past are no longer enough to sustain the effort in this game, especially when it appears they're no longer shared by whoever is directing this, now.The "new" starting story is very much on rails, and should be easier for someone who has never played it before. Some of the new story with its enhanced scenery is even pretty cool. But further along its handholding turns into handwaving away the things that matter, and now I reluctantly raise my own hand to say goodbye.

content:
9, 2014
												The beta builds for Firefall in 2012 were so much better than this current build, and by that I mean around Aug/Sept/Oct time; cuase I didn't really get to play the beta as much as I would have, since something happened to my client, it's wouldn't run or even uninstall. I didn't get to play Firefall again till it was on steam a week or so ago.They took most, if not all, the fun out of this game. The areas are level based now, I remember being able to roam the whole map just about. The random events are gone as far as I can see. No more invasions by the melting or chosen, I remember watchtowers being attacked all the time, and random invasions here and there; don't see any happening now. The crashed thumpers and LGV's are still here, but seem to be fewer than before to me.Then there's the crafting and reaserch. There wasn't any research when I was playing beta. I don't mind it, but they put in TOO much; it needs to be combined and have AT LEAST 50% of it cut out. Either that or make a lot of other ways to get reaserch points other than savalaging, or reduce the points costs as well. And what happened to all the minerals? There's nothing but sand/dirt and iron now that I found around the starting area, there used to be at least a third mineral too around the starting area.I also remember a horizontal skill/gear/weapon tree that you got a point (or whatever) to spend on every level up for a frame; that was option based, as in every level of the tree had at least two choices (such as between two weapons, a weapon or skill, booster/gear item or something else, and etc.) and you could always wait another level to get the second (or other choices) if you wanted both (or all). There was also a particular "upgrade" path to advanced frame 1 or advanced frame 2, so you could get to an better frame quick if so wanted, or both advanced frames.And there's durablity now, and for EVERYTHING? Wasn't in the beta and we don't need it.I'd really like to know wtf happened to this game, it was so much better in the beta when I played it. Which is usually the opposite of betas/games I've played, usually the beta sux more so then the release for a game; but not this time, firefall beta was much better then released firefall.

number of helpful: 17 of 19 people (89%) found this review helpful
content:
er 6, 2016
												I cant make a definitive decision on this game as the entire things has been turned on its head: I'll explain.When this game released, the game's creators clearly wanted a system to have class and area progression much like you see in the mmorpg genre.   they had a complex crafting system and dual currencies to support the free-to-play business model.  After establishing these, they started adding PVP systems into the game.   nothing lik factions, but instanced arena setups much like you see in class-based shooters like team fortress and unreal.  it was participative and completely optional, but had its own progression and rewards system, as you can expect in amodern shooter.   some time after this, they moved focus back to the storyline and the thin mission system that would move you through the lives of 3 main characters, represented with some voice acting and dialog.  This, also, was completely optional, once you left a tutorial area.   This is where the good times seemed to end, as after a few months, I logged in to a completely different game.   I logged in and gone were the class progression elements of classes, and imposed were new inventory limits, changes, and systems.      Frames (the suits that your character wears,)  now had more slots and gear, and the gear was relegated into level resstrictions and tiers.   Frame guns were no longer tied to the role of the class, and could be mixed and matched.  and the complex crafting system that could produce guns with a huge variety of effects had been reduced to a much smaller gear table, with a diablo-rune attachment system.   frames were no longer progresseive, but standalone and purchaseable without any requirement but currency (paid or earned.)  and the free-roaming world had been consolidated into a hub to go on various instanced dungeons.   in short: every sandbox piece of this game had been stripped and relegated into a theme park I did not want to visit.     After some research, this seems to be the result of internal restructuring in the company, that included changing enough of the design team to completely omit the original creators.  So while at first I heavily reccomended this to anyone with a decent system, I say, now, that this is just another game in the pile of theme park, microtransactive mmos with very little to drive a player to progression or exhistence.

number of helpful: 93 of 157 people (59%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
r 7, 2014
												Firefall is a open-world game that is fun for the first several hours, but then gets repetitive as there is not a whole lot to do besides begin leveling the upgraded counterpart after getting max rank. The game starts you off landing on copacobana, a resort town surrounded by a beach on one side and a forest on the other. You have multiple battleframes to choose from to suit your play style, such as the assault, recon, or the engineer. With each battleframe you get to max level you can unlock a advanced frame that sports new abilities and access to a new primary weapon. The world allows you to reach max level without touching a job board do to the abunance of ares missions that are scattered around the map. They will give you as much if not more experience than doing a job board mission in a fraction of the time, however the game is a huge grindfest and gets downright aggravating at times. The gameplay is alot like a watered down borderlands mixed with warframe. You fight dangerous wildlife, rouge bandits, and the infamous chosen which is humanitys main foe. There is not a whole lot to do in the game besides grind, grind, and grind some more.  After leveling my second battleframe I tried yet again to begin leveling another battleframe, but i couldn't bring myself to go through the tedious grind for a third time.When i was reading chat, every now and then the conversation would lean toward talking about the beta and how great it was compared to the way it is now. I did not have the chance to play the beta, but then i think i would be even more dissapointed in the game like so many others who have played and reviewed this game. It is very repetive, lacks content, and is honestly a snoozefest that couldn't keep my interest. Save yourself the time and the hard drive space for something better than Firefall.

r 21, 2016
												Wow, I really hate to write a bad review of this game as I had praised it for so long. After a resource wipe, two gear wipes, a battle frame(one I really enjoyed) removed, and a complete change to the core of how the game is played I really can't say I like this game anymore. I was a Founder, I believed in how the game was created in beta and when it launched the first time. I made friends and even joined a good guild. Currently, with all the new changes this is no longer Firefall.Sure there were some positive steps in the right direction, but there were just too many in the wrong.Back in the day "thumping" was the way you not only aquired resources, it was a great way to level up as well. This brought people together as it was almost impossible or the avarge player to solo the largest resource collector.I heard crys for missions, and how the crafting system sucked. In all honestly, I belive the people crying for this were trying to turn the game into something else they had left before. The Devs listened to these morons and not the playerbase that was spending money, time, and enjoyment to this game as it was. Adding to the game would have been great, however trying to add new stuff seemed too hard and was deemed easier to just redo the game.If the game alright? I don't see why not, however my faith had been spit on, dragged through the dirt, and anything I tried to work for was stripped away from me.If you have never played Firefall I would say jump in and try it out. Don't spend money though as that just seems to promote stupidity.If you played the game before, just keep moving along. Your heart will break and you may constantly say things like, "Where's my x?" or "What am I playing?".

number of helpful: 12 of 13 people (92%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2016
												Well guess its about time for me to finally write a review. Just going to start off by saying I've been around with Firefall for ages now, all the way back since closed alpha, hell my character is still the same original one. Over the years I have seen A LOT of core game changes, like so many I don't even remember all of them. A few changes were for the better, such as when progression was sideways, you aren't trying to gain levels but work on aspects about your frames by gathering resources to use. At least to memory this was my favorite of the systems, it was good. So right now we're sitting at version 1.7 if I'm not wrong, and yet again more changes to the core systems. Battleframe cores, which wasn't something I liked all that much to begin with, are now gone and replaced with generic armor pieces.  Old modules were replaced with new ones, honestly can't tell you why this was changed. Best guess is to have one kind of module rather than weapons and ability varients, still all in all I don't know why this even happened. Entire weapon classes have been changed, and this one seriously pisses me off. Rhinos are one of the dreadnaught arctype frames that used to carry a laser heavy machine gun, it was pretty awesome, and it worked basically how it sounds, a machine gun that shoots lasers. It also had an alternate fire that was a fairly neat and useful single continuous beam. Well the new Photon Lance has all the features of the old laser HMG, but without the machine gun part. To put it bluntly, what used to be an alt fire is now a completely standalone weapon. Oh it also has a fantastic range of 20 meters which basically puts the least defensive of the slow dreadnaught frames at a very close range to the enemy. Makes complete sense obviously. Look, Firefall is my baby. It is a game that I've been coming back to time and time again over the ages, no other MMO has ever received the same treatment from me. I care about this game a lot, and I seriously want it to succeed, believe me. Just... someone out there has decided to shoot themselves in the foot in a really bad way, in the past Firefall has been amazing and fun as hell. That Firefall isn't what we have anymore, its a shame honestly. Well, with the game's constant history of changes maybe we'll see something good again in the future, but I don't think so.

												I was a founder for this game years ago back when it was a mmo shooter with rpg elements and an expansive crafting system. I took some time off to deal with life things only to come back to a game that lost most of its shooter elements to be replaced by meaningless rpg fodder and a handicapped crafting system. The game as it stands is a grinder with little redeemable qualities. You will empty entire clips into one enemy. You will traverse long distances to redo the same quest. And calldowns no longer work correctly.I think everyone should take the time to play this game for a few hours. It has its charms but should serve more as a museum piece for what the industry could be doing. Imagine that when I played this game religiously I was one soldier in a massive war spanning the entire Copacobana region with Chosen attacking all sectors. It was a fight where people in the chat had to determine on the fly what we would hold and what we would let fall due to manpower constraints. As a Recon, I held off Chosen at the Thump Dump Watchtower for half an hour until enough reinforcements could arrive. It reminded me of the glory of Tabula Rasa. Now you can sprint through all these areas with near impunity. There is no war. There is only the grind.

content:
5, 2014
												That may be a tad harsh, but this game is still in development purgatory. Constant system overhauls and removing content to "easy fix" sometimes non-existent issues are very common, and its likely that if you enjoy something about this game it will be gone or completely different a few months later. What was once an open sandbox has now been molded into a traditional path of "hubs" divided by level. A very fun dynamic invasion system in which you had to defend outposts against the main antagonists has been removed as not to disrupt this new leveling experience. The spawn rate for what are called "ARES Missions" has also been reduced to curb EXP gain, along with the removal or nerfing of a few other fun events. Long story short, these developers aren't capable of taking a step forward without taking two or three back. Download it, try it, but do not get invested because you WILL be let down.

number of helpful: 16 of 22 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
y 12, 2016
												Firefall left me with an excellent first impression, and I reveled in it with a small group of my friends for a week.It presented itself with immersive gameplay, as it offered a open world atmosphere, fantastic random encounters across the map, and a voiced operator that guided you along your quests. The combat was a bit bland and minimalistic, but was decent for an MMO shooter, and allowed for a swift learning experience. Team cooperation for random encounters and bosses was encouraged, and a PvE environment allowed a friendly, and helpful community to thrive.The premium currency in this game is a wonderful thing to have to quicken the rate in which you advanced through the game, but wasn't a necessity. The art style didn't knock my socks off, but it worked with their futuristic, yet sort of leisurely, and laid-back feel of the environment. It was in a Post-Apocalyptic scenario, so I wish the game's storyline would cohere with a darker, more serious tone, to prevent the game from looking like a "Paradise Paintball" a bunch of pre-teens would play.What disappointed me, and led to the desertion of this game that I once thoroughly enjoyed, was the lack of apparent progression. The developers seemed to have forgotten to polish some key aspects of MMO's that made them fun. Levels, new abilities, and gear did not provide any distinct differences in playstyle, and offered little pleasure in using. The game unfortunately ended up in a grind, with run-of-the-mill quests that rewarded you with a whole lot of dissatisfaction. I wanted to keep in touch with the game, by waiting for new content, but by that time, my friends were already bored, and subsequently abandoned the game.4/10. I'd recommend this game to those with a couple friends that want to fool around for a while, but is not a game you should invest a lot of time or money in.Warframe fits the same Free-To-Play, Sci-Fi niche, and offers a better arsenal of weapons and classes.

number of helpful: 10 of 11 people (91%) found this review helpful
content:
r 22, 2016
												If your looking for an experience player who went through the whole story mode and beat the game. here I am! Lets talk about the game and what it used to be. Firefall used to be a game where you and a squad of your firend or people you met along the way would explore the vast world and fight side by side until the end. Getting wonderous loot and special bounties were collected and were largely rewarded, upon be finished. The game was great through alpha and beta, it was a one of a kind game, giving us the only good game in the world that was free and had no game changing elements put into the real currency market. Firefall's market was like no other I have experienced, it was a living stock market judged solely on the players. The world price of an item could change from 100 credits to just under 37 credits in just one minute if someone wanted it to. Sometimes that did happen, and the world felt so alive with thousands of players on ech server making it almost impossible to run into someone not wanting to team up with you. Players actively traded and made group agreements through the Faction system they had and still have today. Players made the cities feel like real cities interacting with the enviroment, making large scale wars against eachother in battle arenas or entire 30 man units agianst an armada of chosen endlessly spawning in the shadows. Players would make parties for each other when special events came up, For me New years was that day, 3,500 people showed up on the server to celebrate, some had their whole family playing, some were just getting on for the first time looking for friends. It was an amazing time to play the game. Soon they limited the size of the servers to reduce lag, understandable, but soon after this reduced it even more and more and more over time. Soon only 5 people could be on a server at a time. They decrease the spawn rate on monsters, made events more controlled and less loot worhty, made the market automatically reset every day, players started dropping from the game, akmost a thousand a day until only about 150 a day were online a day. When I was playing in the good days of the game, the highest it got for players, was around 30,000 or more in one day. The highest a week later was 20,000 soon it was 600 now it's around 250.Players lost interest extensively a the 1.6 update came about. anyone who has played it knows what im talking about. 1.6 was the supposed best update to the game. we were all excited until the news of what it was, was leaked. they were changing the way upgrades worked, they were removing 32 items needed for crafting. They were removing crafting all together, and they also removed most people's progress in the game. Me personally, I lost all 6 characters I had, All around levels 25-37. I sent in a report of the problem but never got a response, all I got in return were 16 cases of equipment and a forced character change. I didn't even get to choose my new character. I was forced to be sniper. I decided to deal with it and play out the game as a sniper. Just to see if it was all that bad. at about level 15 sniper is OP. now in my sake sniper is OP after level 5, I recived a gun that could deal 2500 damage and instakill anything no mater where I hit it. At level 32 now, and I have a gun that can do around 5500 damage. I can one hit kill players by hiting them anywhere I feel like. I can kill the end game boss in three hits and can't die because of my healing. It gets boring when you can't die by anything in the game and can kill everything. So I bought something for $5 a skin. though I might as well make mysel look a little more interesting if im going to join someone's squad. guess what, I never recived the skin. contacted customer support and they said they don't offer refunds. They basically told me "Sorry yo can't have your money even though you didn't get what you paid for! Bye forever!" and never got a response since. If you really want to play it, make sure you have at least 5 friends to play with. it makes the game fun with friends. Don't spend money ever, because you have a chance of just being robbed. In all honesty don't play the game at all. The origonal developers have stopped developing it for about a year now. the first director that was fired from directing Firefall is now making a new game called Ember. You can look it up if you like. This new game is supposed to be what Firefall was aimed to be. with the inteanded actors that were removed from Firefall. As of reasearching the forum site they made, right now they are making concept art and taking in suggestions on what they should do for the game.(EDIT):The game has become better although the problems still persist. although the game is a lot better then when I wrote this review back then.

y 28
												I've played this game for several years now, since it was in closed beta. Back then, it was a incredible game, it was unique, I loved the open world pve features the most and being new to this genre of gaming I settled right in and wasted many hours on the game. Over the years, updates were just going backwards, with every update they were removing features that made this the unique game that it was. Now, it's pretty much the same as any other game in it's genre. It's all about levelling up your characters and that's it. They took awat crafting which was one of my favourite parts. The storyline missions were gaining more and more bugs with each update, dropship transport was introduced (great!) then removed shortly after due to more bugs. At one time, this game had huge potential, it could have been so much more than it is today, it could have had a hhuge thriving future but sadly the development team messed this up as much as they possibly could.As it stands now, the game is no longer in development. There are no developers left at the company, so I'm guessing it will continue to work in it's current form until the server money runs out whenever that may be. It really is such a shame to see such a great opportunity for a game be thrown down the trash as this one has.For anyone considering Firefall, I would suggest to wait for Em-8er which is created by Mark Kern, the genuis who came up with Firefall. Em-8er promises to be what Firefall could have been.
