content:
1, 2016
I loved Firefall. I really, truly, did.But after years of changes, it's not the game it was.I have a lot of time in this game, a lot of memories from playing it. I leveled every frame to 40, kitted them all out. Crafted my own gear, got a full custom prefixed loadout on my Rhino, got supremely lucky and netted a pair of Celestial Wings. I met some really amazing people in Firefall, had a great time hanging out with my army in teamspeak.I joined when the game first came up on Steam, summer of 2012, after following the game since the first concept art appeard on the internet. The world was beautiful, the art and design bold and striking. The community was friendly and strong. The sounds were amazing. The distant pounding of a thumper, the crisp report of an assault rifle, the whine and hum of jetpacks. Movement was free and unconstrained. Jetpacks opened up a thousand possibilities for combat and exploration, gliders made for amazing screenshots and travel unlike anything else I'd seen.I played heavily for a year or so, then left once I'd reached endgame and the content had run out. I'd done all of the instances countless times, farmed Bane, Kana, WF, Miru when it came out, ground HC campaign tokens.I came back, years later, to a game which bore little resemblance to the one I'd left. More reminiscent of a Nexon MMO than the vibrant world I remembered, I didn't find any of the magic that pulled me into the game left. Countless changes had rendered hours of effort worthless, the community was virtually nonexistant. The game was more grind-oriented than I'd ever seen it. Most of the things that made the game stand out were gone or had been rendered irrelevant. Players who I'd run raids with had been offline for months. I played for a few hours here and there but it was pointless.I sincerely wish things had gone differently. This game remains one of my favorites. I may have joined after the golden age of the beta was over, but I still got a good bask in the sunset. Now, with the game seemingly dying, with devs being laid off and rumors of an impending server shutdowns looming large, there is little or no reason to start playing.This review is less of a review, more of a eulogy. There was a lot to love about Firefall. While it was up it was easy to stand back and hope for updates, roll my eyes at the changes. Now that Firefall is coming to an end, I have realized that I will miss it greatly when it leaves us for good.Goodbye, Red5. Goodbye, Firefall.

content:
9, 2014
												FREE TO PLAY done RIGHT!Most people talk about the grind of the game... yes, there is a grind. Name one MMO that does not have a grind of some fashion... go ahead... I'll wait... That's right, you can't! So while this game has a grind, it's a LOT more satisifying because of the gameplay itself. The fast paced, skill based shooter mechanics are wonderful and help keep the game entertaining. The people that complain about the "grind to unlock advanced battleframes"... they are doing it wrong. Simple as that. While you can spend money to unlock them, or level up to Level 40 with each of the battleframes... you can also buy them off the Auction House with credits you earn in-game. "BUT THAT IS A GRIND!" ... not really! You get a mineral called Crystite that you can directly exchange for Credits. By the time you reach level 15, you can EASILY have enough credits to buy an advanced battleframe. Look under the "Unlocks" tab, they are typically 4-6k credits. At level 22, I have 18k credits. Sell what you dont need.... convert to credits... DONE! In half a day of playing, I have unlocked 4 advanced battleframes. You can also use Credits to buy ANYTHING that you could spend cash on. DO NOT LET PEOPLE FOOL YOU because they didnt see the information right in front of their eyes.Yes, questing consists of going to a Job Board, accepting a quest, and turning it back in. This can feel grindy, but remember... name an MMO that doesnt do this? The difference is that you also have world events going on almost 100% of the time. So jump in and help defend or attack a location. You don't even have to be there for the full encounter... just kill a few things and you will get FULL credit for completion.  Leveling is incredibly fast if you get into the habit of actually looking at what is going on in the world around you.The customization options in this game are AMAZING! You can freely switch the way you look, your battleframe's colors/patterns, your cosmetic gear, etc... at any of the "New You" stations or Battle Garage (located in every quest hub, city, and outpost. They are everywhere!You can spend money... or you can simply look at what the game has to offer... You can buy ANYTHING and EVERYTHING with in-game credits. You can sell EVERYTHING. And everytime you complete a Job Board quest, you get a token to take to a slot machine for bonus prizes... some of which are worth quite a bit!I HIGHLY recommend this game to everyone. This is game isn't perfect and it is not for everyone... but if you like fast paced shooters with an amazing open world and the ability to jump in and out of encounters, plus being rewarded for helping other players... THIS GAME IS FOR YOU!

number of helpful: 25 of 46 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												Been playing the Firefall beta for just about 3 years now, and it has certainly come a long way! When the closed beta first began, there was little more than instanced PvP on a single map, and Red 5 has slowly but surely fleshed out a MASSIVE and incredibly detailed game world full of activities and adventure.This is not your average shooter, nor is it your average MMO - but rather a truly sandbox world in which you are free to explore and tackle any activity you desire, whether that is completing missions from an ARES Job Board, roaming the world in search of wandering encounters, harvesting minerals while fighting off huge waves of enemies via the process of "Thumping", tackling campaign missions which help tell the story of the world around you, or jumping into a squad with friends and participating in some high level open-world PvP.Starting with the default 5 battleframe archetypes, you will gain access to advanced frames over time which fill more specialized roles. Your character can jump into any of your unlocked battleframes at any time, allowing you to change your playstyle to suit your mood or desired activity. You will level each battleframe individually (similar to leveling a character in a traditional MMO), finding, purchasing, or crafting gear along the way.There are 5 man instances (complete with a "hardcore" mode for high level characters), 20 man end-game raids, and as previously mentioned, a massive open-world PvP zone to explore.For fans of first-person or third-person shooters and action games, I highly recommend checking out the world of New Eden. It can be a bit daunting figuring out what to do at the start, but stick with it, and join an Army early on, so you always have people to play with. You'll be having a blast in no time!Good luck Ares 3-5.

y 23, 2016
												Started playing this game February last year or so (1.3 build) great game, loved it, but this new build ruined all the primary aspects of why i loved playing the game (except the scenery). The scenery is AMAZING, but the battleframes are junk compared to what they were, dont even care about the damage aspect of it, its what they did to the abilities and modules. If i was a new player and 1.6 was my first build to play, then it wouldnt have such an impact other than reading a flooded chat lobby of everyone complaining about how messed up everything is now. 3 major impacts that really ruined what the game was is leading me to not want to play because the way the game was in 1.3 was what i wanted the game to be in terms of abilities/weapons etc. Sure there were some glitches, and some overpowered weapons/abilities/perks, but instead of ballancing that stuff, they trashed everything in a "throw it up in the air" manner. The new method in equiping your battleframe is great how they itemized sections of the frame, the upgrades to the terrain are most excellent, but the mutillation of abilities just makes everything feel week and limited. All the time and effort put into learning, gathering, crafting etc, wasnt properly addressed in the compensation package they offered. All of the modules previously mounted on weapons and abilities are gone now, and salvaging what was left over doesnt cover replacing what was there before. I understand with a new build, there are going to be glitches and bugs etc, but playing the game over to get a far shadow of what was, is really hard to get behind and into.....If you are a "new" player and never played 1.3... GO FOR IT, mute the chat box, and blast away!!! If youre a 1.3 fan, then by all means get your feet wet, but if rhino, bastion or firecat were your top frames, then you decide. Not a fan at all

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
27, 2014
												Horrendously underrated. FireFall is an addictive MMOFPS with a mixure of elements from Borderlands, Sanctum 2, an a little bit of Section 8, and while it doesn't deliver on the best aspect of each one, the way it meshes together is really great, and adds for a fun experience. The way people get together whenever a mission pops up, while not original (I heard Guild Wars 2 has a similar mechanic), is a blast, which raises it above other F2P MMOs, and the gun combat is engaging and satisfying. Progression feels genuine, and more often than not, FireFall does NOT feel like a free to play game, though there are times when it does lose that illusion, such as a store window popping up for "red beans" and cosmetic items.

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
8, 2014
												For those of you out there looking for a god MMOFPS this is not for you. This might as well be WoW with guns. Firefall is extremely grindy as it has moving from Point A to Point B doing mediocre, pointless quests. In the game your supposed to be a baddass soldier defending the last of humanity against an insurmountable enemy called The Chosen. And for atleast the tutorial part of the game it shows this pretty well. But immediately after the tutorial is over you become nothing but an errand boy. In a fact many missions simply have you passing letters or info to different NPCs, yep thats right. And in all the time i've played this game besides the tutorial I never once fought The Chosen not a single time didnt even see them on the map. And all the NPCs have stereo typical accents and extremely shallow personalities and you dont care about any of them. And like every other typical free-to-play it tries to ♥♥♥♥♥ out money by punishing those whose dont buy the deluxe version or buy "Red Beans" the ingame shop currency. For example if I wanted to get one of the Advanced Battleframes as they call it would have to either grind for dozens if not hundreds of hours doing repeated boring combat (It mostly consists of killing gangsters or bugs that is it) and quests all the while listening to completely forggetable NPCs. OR I could buy the battleframe for a  low price of 9.99$! The crafting system is mediocre at best and adds even another level of grinding onto it with you having to collect many various resources and components by either killing enemies or defend mobile mining equipment. Also even once you have all the ingredient you have to refine them which if you happen to have alot can take to upwards of an hour to do so. Then theres the research tree which is literally completely horizontal and can take literally days sometimes for higher tier stuff. Now the world while large and can be at times interesting is HORRIBLY textured unless your on the highest settings. But most of the time your to busy to notice anything about it as your constantly being shot at by enemies. And since the world is so large its hard to get from location to location. Each location you go to is usually on the other side of the map and there is no easy way to get there unless you take one of the ships you have to wait for. Which is pointless if your doing a quest as those have you 99% of the time running as far out into the forest to locations you've already been to. Now the weapon and abilities are probably the best aspect of the game as many of them can be quite satisfying at times. But the only reliable way to get them is through the god awful crafting and research system. I dont recommend this game to anyone you are far better off using your time to play something else. And as a person who played the beta for dozens of hours it pains me to say this game could've been something and those who also played will know what im talking about. But this game as it stands now is nothing but typical MMO that fell in line like most of the rest.

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
5, 2014
												I downloaded this game with good hopes, and when I finally started playing it, I lost all hope. This game is 8GB of glitches and bugs.     Most of the quests are simply walking from Point A to Point B, then killing either 5 People with spikes on thier heads and arms who were chosen for something, or killing 30 Crab-Bug things that spawn with different abilities such as the power to commit suicide and slow you down for all of 3 seconds, and usually there is a group of about 5 to 10 Able-Bodied soldiers with Guns and Armor more powerful than yours that are sitting there acting like a civillian and the quest says "HELP them kill 30 Crab-Bug things" yet if they do ever decide to move thier arms up to the gun that is mysteriously floating infront of them and KILL SOMETHING, IT DOESN'T COUNT TOWARDS THE QUEST THEREFORE IT ISN'T HELPING AT ALL! Half the time when you have to kill a large amount of things they barely spawn and when they do the soldiers decide to move thier arms up to the mysteriously floating gun infront of them and kill it before you do and then you don't get to make ANY progress towards the quest and it will take about 10 minutes just for the Crab-Bugs to respawn and then they kill them again and basically from there on it's basically the same thing over and over until you get enough kills to finish the quest, and then it's back to Point A (usually on the other side of whatever town your closest to) and then you get barely any EXP and it takes about 20 more quests like that to get to the next level. And that's just the questing system.    The main reason I even slightly wanted this game was because I heard my friends talking about Motorcycles and Hang Gliding and doing this thing called "Thumping" where they have to defend some sort of mining rig while waves of mobs are thrown at them. Hang Gliding was probably the best part of the game in my opinion, Except for when you even slightly look up your thrown at the ground and your hang glider gets destroyed. You can't even get a Motorcycle until level 25 or apparently if you buy some DLC then you can have it from the start, along with an infinite use Rainbow Hang Gliding Pad. Also, you can't hang glide unless you step on some sort of magic pad on the ground that gives you a hang glider. Did I mention it takes a couple hours of questing to level up?    Another problem I have with this game is the NPC's. The Soldiers will wander around dangerous areas and act like civillians, and the civillians will walk around safe areas acting like they are holding a gun whenever they aren't and acting like a soldier.    And also, the character customization is awesome! (No it's not) Everything is free! (No it's not) And everything totally doesn't require some form of VIP currency! (Yes it does)    I think you should take my advice and NOT DOWNLOAD THIS GAME! IT IS NOT WORTH IT! IT IS VERY GLITCHY AND BUGGY! Unless they take a Hot Iron to the game and Iron out all the bugs, I'm never downloading it again.

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
18, 2014
												Firefall is a shooter FPS, or TPS if you so choose, MMO. I apparently only played two hours (and really, those hours felt a lot longer than that!), but that short time was enough to convince me that Firefall wasn’t the game for me. The overall quality isn’t that great, graphically the game isn’t impressive, the voice acting is atrocious, combat is basic, missions are repetitive and boring. Why bother then?My first gripe with Firefall falls on the graphics, and perhaps even more on the aesthetics. First off, the game isn’t that beautiful. It really isn’t. It might resemble Borderlands, but that’s just from far away. What really annoyed me was the character design, like World of Warcraft meets Gears of War or something, but with way uglier faces. Seriously, some of the guards in town barely have something resembling a human face.Trying to get into the mood of game is made further impossible by the horrendous voice acting. In the first mission, the tutorial mission, planes crash and pilots say something like “going down!”, etc. in the most bored tone possible. It’s right out of a MST3K or Riff Trax show, but while it might be fun for a short while, it will become cringe worthy since the plot of the missions comes in the form of audible conversations.Combat is completely uninteresting: there are enemies, shoot them. The problem is even more apparent when you have to deal with it during the missions. Go from point A to point B, fight monsters. Then fight another wave of monsters. And then a few other waves of the same exact monsters again. Rinse and repeat. How is this supposed to hold my attention? It’s not like there is any difficulty to it too!On a positive note, you can switch character classes easily, but each needs to be levelled up separately. Jet packs and glider wings are a nice way to get around but the world isn’t beautiful enough to go off exploring. It’s functional, nothing more.If some people find Borderlands boring, then Firefall must put them in a coma. And if you don’t find Borderlands boring, then continue playing it, because there is nothing to see here.

content:
0, 2014
												Played this game alot during it's closed and open beta, and I've gotta say they've changed alot of stuff since then. Alot of the changes are pretty nice too.  The beta was a glitchy, buggy, repetitve(thou still could/can be), and kinda boring due to not having any content in the game to be involved with).  Since my few hours or so playing on the steam release I do gotta say....thank god no more half pants battle thongs on my bastion battleframe chick! lol (you beta guys know what i'm talking about). Anyway, here's my pro's and con's so far for new players interested in Firefall...PROS:-Beautiful graphics and not too tolling on mid-grade computers-Action based combat system (no point and click)-Rewarding Dynamic Events-Simple crafting system (All depends on the person, some people like more complex crafting, I just find this one easy to learn and use.) (CRAFTABLE MOTORCYCLE AT LEVEL 25, AFTER DOING BOARD MISSION IN DREDGE CALLED "In the Wheelhouse" *hint hint*)-Guild Wars 2 style market system (trade in-game currency for cash-shop currency system)-Storyline/Personal mission progression added to the game since beta ( looks like they might develop more story later on)-Voice Acting for every mission and dynamic events (note: some of it is a bit amateur, but hey...i've heard worse in dubbed anime)-Leaching from squad thumpers don't hurt the thumper owner now-NO pay to win cash shop grabs; this one is an important one i look at when hopping into a free to play mmorpg. I'm a heavy pvper and the first thing i look at is, is the guy with the fatter wallet gonna kick my ♥♥♥?  This game avoids that 100%, everything in the cash shop is all cosmetic or getting cooler looking  and faster moving mounts and gliders and VIP boosts which just helps speed up leveling and crafting processes.-NO restrictions on free to play usersCONS:-Server stability could be a little better (we'll probly see some fixes for that soon; this could be due to busy servers)   exampes:  -occasional long loading time for missions  -occasional rubber banding -Gets repetitive at times-They are still working on balancing issues between battleframes for pvp-Farm heavy when focusing on crafting-Currency exchange: Red Beans(cash shop currency) can be bought with Credits(Marketplace currency) at a minimum of 100 Credits (Which doesn't bother me personally, but could have some more freedom on that depending on the playerbase economy)-3d modeling on characters could be better aswell as some of the cosmetic customization-Limited content compared to other mmo's (more content in the future i hope)-Able to unlock another battleframe only by getting a battleframe to level 40, using red beans, or buying the battleframe off the marketplace for a few thousand creditsThis is now my final review, now that i've put a good amount of time playing the released game.  I really enjoy this game personally and see much potential for it to develop into a bigger more grand mmo.  Keep in mind that this Pro's and Con's list was made for new players that haven't played beta. There are many things I miss from beta that I personally wish were still in the game, but who knows, maybe they'll add some stuff back in later. Anyway...I highly recomment this game, it's great for what it is. Especially if you're looking for a free to play game that doesn't restrict you heavily unless you got a fat wallet.Thank you for taking the time to read my review and please rate the review as you see fit.

number of helpful: 9 of 15 people (60%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
y 22, 2015
												UPDATE:  Skip to the end for impressions on the new War in the Amazon content and faction changes.I'm coming up on 400 hours of gameplay in this fellow, so I suppose I should write a review of some sort.   Much has already been written about Firefall, and while I recommend the game to anyone looking for an action MMO, I almost feel like anything I say would hardly encapsulate the game because it is always changing and shifting (with a major endgame area to be debuted in the next few weeks after I write this).I suppose what most people want to know when reading user comments on this game is: is it actually free to  play or is it "Freemium" nonsense where the game is basically unplayable past a certain point without investing lots of money?  Well, I can definitely attest: this game really and truly is free to play.  There is no content behind paywalls and while real money can, in theory, buy you better in-game equipment and such, everything in the game can be obtained, in some manner, through gameplay.   Now, I won't lie....paying for the VIP membership is probably the smart course for a player who enjoys the game, but the game is not unplayable without it.  People who spend lots of real money for in-game currency to buy stuff off the player market will have an advantage in PvP, I won't lie, but as PvP is an entirely seperate part of the game, the PvE kinda benefits from having some people with purchased items.  Having said all that, here's my brief pros/cons rundown:Pros:-Interesting variations in gameplay and playstyle based on the class you choose.-The perk system allows interesting synergies between different classes since the different classes can actually share most of the perks that you earn from leveling.-The game only uses ONE character who has access to all of the class "Frames", which makes sharing equipment easier and helps with leveling frames that are around the same level.-The singleplayer "jobs" actually bother to try telling a coherent story about the setting and background of the game.-A healthy amount of open world content that gives players a break from just doing jobs to level their frames.-Once you complete major milestones in the game once (like unlocking new areas etc.) the stuff unlocks for your successive frames, so you have more freedom and options with your lower level frames as you get further into the game.-Large-scale open world events allow for fun, co-op play with other players without being too exclusionary for lower level or newer players (although there are some basic level limits on certain things).-The ability to "thump" (mine for your own crafting resources) adds an interesting, self-initiated activity to the game.-Players share exp and loot for open world events in a very fair manner and no one player can either take all the rewards or prevent other players from getting their rewards either.Cons:-The game balance, in terms of overall difficulty, is problematic at times and is always being tinkered with.  (as I write this, major updates to how combat functions are being planned probably to be implimented in the next month or two)-A fairly good chunk of the usual bugs and glitches that large, open world MMOs have.  Some are generally fixed fairly fast, while others have been around for ages without hope of being fixed any time soon.-Getting around the world can be awkward and slow even with vehicles and gliders and other assistance.  One entire section of the game (Sertao, the world for characters lvl 25-35) has no means of quick travel at all except to go back to the exit/entrance travel points.  -The "advanced" frames are sometimes very superior to the normal, free, counterparts, making the base frames a little on the weak or disadvantaged side.-The major server events do not happen with anywhere near enough frequency, in my opinion.  All major events at this point only occur once an hour which can sometimes make areas of the game very barren of content depending on the time of day.-Special open world content rated for single players is not even remotely able to be finished by solo players, and often requires several people.-The in-game crafting system, while very useful and functional for character up to about level 30-32 becomes so insanely grindy and impractical in the later game that there is almost no point in using it to supply characters above lvl 32 or so.-Some of the instances and special missions have serious issues with what kind of loot they reward.  This is slowly being improved, but right now it is often not worth the time it takes to do some of the more advanced, end-game instances and such.Like any MMO, there are players who take a lot of things about this way too seriously and will often have a negative effect on the overall community, but anyone who just wants to have fun taking out some bad guys and maybe joining some large-scale events will find a lot to like here.  Just be aware that a lot of content and features have been added to the game over a relatively short period of time, so things are always being tweaked and modified.  The community, in general, has been very positive and the strong focus on PvE means that most players understand the benefits of helping out each other.  If, however, you are looking for PvP, Firefall might not satisfy you much.  While the game has an entire world set aside for PvP, it suffers from a few major problems; mostly balance and the fact that not many people play in those areas.  PvP will probably undergo major changes as well in the coming months, but right now I cannot reccomend Firefall for people who want the PvP aspect as a strong element of the game.Damn...it's almost impossible to really get into everything in this game except to say: just give it a try for a bit and see what you think.  The community is usually pretty helpful and I always try my best to help out newer players.  There is also a strong "mentor" system in the game where players get appointed as mentors.  A few of the mentors are jerks, but they get weeded out pretty fast.Oh, and one more thing...the game is very playable with an Xbox controller (support for which is built-in) but you will have to fiddle with it to get it where you want it.  There are a lot of hot keys in the game and it's not possible to operate the entire game witn a controller, but the bulk of the game (running around and shooting things) can be done very well with a controller.UPDATED STUFF:  So, not long after I wrote this, Red 5 did indeed add the "War in the Amazon" content and a new faction system, which changes some aspects of my review.The Amazon is a new region of the game geared solely towards high-level, end-game characters (the game says it's only for level 40 players, but I think level 37+ could probably handle themselves OK)  It's difficult to describe the region if you are not already familiar with the game, but to summarize it, it's basically just a place for lvl 40 characters to go nuts because there's nearly constantly combat.  It's a lot of fun, but as usual, one of the downsides is that the rewards are not that great and you need a lot of people to take over the region.   The new faction system is amazing and gets rid of so much of the grind.  Instead of having to slowly earn faction currency to buy things, you now just permanently earn reputation and can buy things with crystite (which is the standard currency) when you reach the appropriate faction level.  No more spending days of your life just trying to buy some high level abilities or weapons.

content:
, 2015
												Firefall. A name that means bugger all, yet is still easily insulted. Firefall is an FPSMMORPG and maybe some other letters of the alphabet with lyrics within songs that suspiciously remind of you of ♥♥♥♥. What kind? ♥♥♥♥ed if I knew, the blue kind that comes out of Aranhas. The crab-like ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s within this game. You could even add RTS genre if you were commanding the monsters against the worthless human scum-- Which sounds like a much better game.Anyway, Firefall is of a genre that even when abbreviated is longer than its actual full name. But at least games no longer have fifty seven digits after them, or enough colons to make a hard drive dry heave into the jet-blasters.Oh, right, Firefall. The story starts after everything interesting happened, where the terrans, no not those ones, discover a space rock, made a ship from it because they suddenly know what space rock does, And then smashed it into the planet for plot! Well, that's my guess at least. They don't really explain why the ship crashes into the earth. Either way you were hired to use gun on bandit. Possibly smash it in the face- which is actually a more viable strategy than the guns that might as well fire BB'S. Unless you're the assault where the BB's shatter. Though, there aren't really that many bandits, it's mostly the wildlife because that's suddenly more dangerous than human with gun.Actually, everyone whinges about these space f*cks that invade earth or whatever, but you never see them until about 10 hours in, or perhaps the story quests that you only have within the first area. But who cares about the story? Well, Me. The sole patrionist of Single player. Though the story is fun, I guess. But again, it's only in the first area, so there's nothing to interest you after the first area.Too many negatives! I need to put my smiley mask on and dance around this pile of ♥♥♥♥ pretending to look I know what I'm doing, I mean until I find a good spot, like looking for carrot within vomi- I can't use that analogy because that's not hard to fin- OH I FOUND ONE! The class system is probably the best part of the game. There are five classes, 11 more that you can unlock either by dinging to level 40 with one class or using micro <Dry heave> micro transactions. "But wait!" I hear you say. "I thought you were going to talk about the good parts?" Oh, ♥♥♥♥, right. Well, you can change class whenever you find a station. You essentially change clothes, but whatever ♥♥♥♥ing reason you forget all your old skills and abilities or whatever. You do keep all your crafting <dry heave> stuff. What is it with MMO's - Wait, with ANY game now days that includes crafting. You keep all your weapons too. Though for some stupid ♥♥♥♥offing reason you have limited inventory space eventhough you have to keep everything for every single class ever. And to finish the game 100% you have to play the game about 16 timesI've managed this long without mentioning Navi- I mean the Goddess- I mean cu- Oh f*ck it, Aero. It's your decision on whatever you call her. Perhaps a French/Russian Navi who likes reminding you how what a "great job" you did "taking out that bandit camp". F*ck off Navi, I was hiding in the corner sucking my thumb because I was an engineer who was only good for hiding behind his turret, and demanding it to do all the work.Though if you've ever played the game, you would be yelling at me that it is pretty. The game is split into three sections, Coral forest, Desert, volcano. You can already see where this is going, can't you? The game starts out beautiful, and then suddenly Brown. Brown everywhere! Like you mixed all your colours together and threw them against the monitor. I actually quite enjoyed Firefall in Coral forest. It had the story mission, beautiful areas, fun missions and you didn't want to hang every character you met.You then get to the second area which is a pain in my ♥♥♥♥ to navigate. You get a vehicle at the start of the area, which is nice, but what the f*ck is that going to do when the rest of the game mostly has canyons? There are also consumable glider pads which make navigation that much more fun from higher areas, but I swear the canyons were designed to be big enough for you to not be able to fly over. It is as if they do not want you to get to your destination. One town genuinely has been walled off so there's only one way in.So previously the game was in all the colours of the rainbow, which enjoyed dancing across the room, jumping into your eyes then f*cking your ear lobe. You then enter desert land, lava land with so much brown you would confuse it with a modern FPS. OH WAIT--

content:
ry 3, 2016
												The name is accurate now, for it fell, and it is most certainly burning.Ignore my hours, as I actually have played this game off-steam.Firefall is a game that has been plagued with bad decisions for some time now. Almost as long as it's been losing players, in fact. Slowly, but steadily, the game shifted from amazing me with its quality, to instead amazing me with just how terrible the devs could prove themselves to be. It's kind of like most shows on TV these days, with the only exception being that you don't come in with the expectation of it being terrible from the get-go.With the most recent update, the game finally stopped clinging onto mixed-quality limbo and dropped into the flaming pit of no return, screaming in agony with Electronic Arts, Activision, Ubisoft, Aeria Games, Nexon, and Perfect World Entertainment. Purchased by a Chinese company, Firefall was pressured into pushing out an update that wasn't even ready, and my goodness was it ever not ready. "The update that killed Firefall" as the community calls it, has essentially taken what little good there was left in the game and thrown it out the window. Or rather, that's what I would say, except they actually did that quite some time ago, so really what's going on here is they dragged the game back in, decided it wasn't dead enough, so they then drove a knife through its heart and threw it from the roof instead of the window, then finally ran out there with a hammer and hit it once, just to be sure. In one single update, this has gone from a good free to play title with a few flaws to "how not to run an F2P 101".No quality remains. You can salvage more from the debris of a nuclear apocalypse than you can from this game. The only thing between this game and death is the server being shut down. If you are a new player debating whether or not to play this game, I STRONGLY recommend you decide against it, for all you will be doing is wasting your bandwidth, harddrive space, and time. There are many other F2P games out there, and at this point, almost all of them are better than this.Even if you much prefer tormenting yourself with repetitive gameplay, bad design choices, and bugs, you'd still be better served with the latest CoD title instead. Because this game is so bad now, that even if you were - for some reason - wanting to play a game that was bad, you'd still feel that this was too terrible for you.

content:

												A thin, empty, boring, and pointless game of go-there-kill-that in which the only goal seems to be progression for progression's sake; hit the next battleframe level and research the next weapon level, always for miniscule, uninteresting stat increases. 												I can't get over how clean this game is. Everything seems incredibly accessible, tightly packed and gorgeous. A few UI hiccups and the normal MMO bugs like odd mob spawning and lag seem to be worked around so it's not too bad.I played a bit of closed beta so I'm glad to see this game finally released, I'll update my review after I get a few more levels and hours!*Edit* 17 hours in and I'm addicted. I've been craving an MMO and FF far exceeded my expectations. I wish it was a bit more FPS than MMO but I can't complain. For a f2p, this game is tight. Better than most current MMO's.*57 Hours Edit* Well I'm almost level cap and I'm excited to play a new class tomorrow for the actual launch. I'm thinking engineer but I want to hit 40 to get a pilot token and unlock Dragonfly.I'm upset there's hardly any low level pvp, and I'll give a new edit after I hit cap and kill other people. I'm excited, but almost 60 hours in and I'm almost level cap with the 25% bonus experience, I'm very sure that there's not enough choices when it comes to grinding to get to cap level without VIP status. So while I want to say it'd be an extra 20 hours of grinding, it's even worse than that, because there's hardly enough missions after level 20 to get to the next level appropriate zone even with the Exp Boost. You'll probably end up running around, looking for ARES missions, crashed lgvs/thumpers and tornados.Unless you just want to Thump all day with people. It's a damn good thing that's actually fun to do.

content:
1, 2014
												Pretty good game. Not for the lone wolf-type players. (usually). Seems to be, a little lack-luster in the concept-area (post-public-patch that is), but the ideas and concepts that are present prove quite satisfying. Me being terrible at everything FPS, this game is rough for me. Though some call this an "RPGFPS," I would simply say it's an FPS with a decent story. Character customization is simple, but enjoyable. Not much -more- effort other than the option -to- customize your character is apparent at the moment. (a.k.a. no customizing hair under a particular hat you like, no customizing your "undersuit" that goes under your Battleframe). Not deeply customizeable, yet as I said, the options available have been of amiable satisfaction to me. Enough to enjoy the game.In all sincerity, do NOT approach this game as a die-hard FPS. YOU WILL BE DISAPPOINTED. This game was not INTENDED to be a die-hard FPS. For those of you that have those split-second reaction-speeds and superior reaction times, this game might be a bit of a breeze for you.Most importantly, this game is STRONGLY based on community. Something I LOVE about this game. It's the only real reason I can/come back to, this game. Alot of good players on this game that enjoy both investing themselves, as much as helping others.My rating on a scale of 1-to-5?2. (maybe 2.5)Most definitely worth playing. Maybe even worth a couple of bucks to buy some fun in-game material.(This rating is opinion-based, and comes strongly from the stand-point of an RPG player. Not an FPS player).

												Firefall... It's a mix of 'whoa' and 'eeh' kind of game. I can't quite describe it with precise word, but that's how I feel. I, for one, quite liking the lore. Guns, someone died, loot.- The currency system is well thought out, you can't be a poor guy, because currencies are interchangable.- The quests... It's uuh... pile of mess, to put it kindly. It's not called grinding, it's called a chore, almost slavery.The reason I still give it thumbs up because I (maybe you) really enjoyed the first half of the journey. After level 25, the novelty is gone.

content:
4, 2014
												Firefall is the MMO worth playing. It is free to play. You do not have to pay to win, but I would advise a player to at least  buy a glider and bike for traveling purposes. While you can get both without having to pay, it is worth the early investment for time.  I use the glider probably as much or more than the bike. The advanced frames (classes)are unlocked by maxing your level on the regular ones, or you can buy a new frame with the in-game currency. Most real money expenses come from cosmetics an short xp buffs. You don't need them to do well. The classes are all useful in one way or another. The "Thumping" in the game is very enjoyable. Thumping is a way of mining, which is basically a "Protect this drill and kill everything that tries to eat it" game. There are invasions where the enemy Chosen will try to take over a city. There are real consequences if you let them do that (no access to quests/vendors in the area until it is retaken). The storyline is also worth looking into; it will enrich the traveling and questing experience.

number of helpful: 15 of 27 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
0, 2014
												Not interested in a full review? Well here you go: This game is awesome, one of the best developers (if not the best). Can't see any pay-to-win either. Is pretty grindy, but hey, it's an MMO. Just try it.I've been in beta for nearly 2 years. This game was in beta for an eternity, because Red 5 actually wanted to release a good game, not like many others today, releasing half-finished/broken games.Nearly every game system/mechanic has been overhauled a dozen times, which, in my oppinion, shows, that they really want to find the best systems for this game.The developers really listen to the community and are overall just awesome.The game itself has awesome graphics, has a customizable UI and allows UI addons.The story itself seems solid so far, but further episodes are not out yet. Most of the missions are replayable instances which are actually really fun. They also feature hardcore modes with all enemies at the maximum level.The level cap is set at 40, though there are 16 frames (which are kind of like classes) that all have to be levelled individually. To earn experience you either do the mission instances, ARES Jobs/mission which are comparable to repeatable quests in many MMORPGs, do open world events or thump. I'd recommend getting some friends in, since higher quality thumpers (for better resources) and high level ARES Jobs are pretty hard.What is thumping? It's basically mining. You call down a thumper which attracts enemies and has to be defended by you. Once it's full you recall it and get resources, which are used for crafting.Crafting is one of the major aspects in this game. It's one of the ways to acquire better gear. You can also rely on drops, but it will probably take quite some time to find, what you're looking for.The areas are vastly different, you will encounter pretty much everything from frozen to desert, with according enemies.If you're ever bored, just go around and explore the world.The nice thing is: You can go nearly everywhere on the map, no matter the level. You will probably be dying a lot in the high level areas, but it's not all about levels... if you are good at the game, you can also handle high level enemies. It's skill-dependent up to a certain degree.The movement is also very unique in Firefall. You can walk and run, of course, but there are also Light and Medium Ground Vehicles to transport you faster. You have jumpjets, which are like jetpacks. You have enough energy to go about 3 seconds into the air, but it quickly recharges. This system allows for advanced movement. Another way to move around the world are "gliders", which will launch you a few meters in the air and give you temporary wings, allowing you to glide through the air. If you want to go from one major town to another, you can also use the Dropships, which are free. Just enter them and wait to arrive at your destination. You can also directly teleport, but that (at least right now) costs a ridiculous amount of money.There are 5 different types of frames, each with 3 (one with 4) different frames.-Assault, which is focused on mobility and damage. The primary damage is a type of plasma cannon, firing a ball of energy, which explodes on impact.-Biotech, the healer/poison class, has different primary weapons, depeding on the frame you choose-Dreadnaught. Tanky Machine gun dudes. One of the frames has many different weapons, from shotguns over SMGs to Assault Rifles.-Engineer, which has a short ranged laser/tesla gun. Supported by his own placed turrets. Can also deploy health/ammo stations, making him a supportive guy.-Recon. Sniper. Depeding on the frame, you can have an auto-sniper or charge rifle.But just because the Biotech for example can heal, that doesn't mean that you don't deal damage, every frame can also survive alone, if the player has some skill, but grouping up is of course more effective.If you like supporting others but are afraid that you can't play alone - don't be afraid, you can. Also, you can always group up with some random people around the world.Each frame type has the "basic" frame and 2 or 3 advanced versions. Once you hit level 40, you can unlock another frame. The advanced frames have some advantages, making them mandatory, if you wanna go all out on Firefall, but if you just want to play it casually, you don't have to do it - the advanced frames are not even 1.5x stronger than the basic ones.As I just said, if you wanna go all out, you'll have to use the advanced ones, because levelling frames will unlock new perks. Perks are passive abilites which you can equip. Perks cost a certain amount of points, depeding on their tier. You have a limited amount of points which depends on your level, so you have to choose the perks that fit your playstyle/frame best.Each frame also has 3 skills plus one HKM. The skills are only limited by cooldown and cover nearly everything. Place turrets, heal teammates, poison enemies, burn them, shoot stuff at them, get more defense, etc.HKMs are kind of like ultimates. They have to charge up (by doing damage) and deal massive damage or provide a massive buff.The game has a marketplace, where you can buy and sell cosmetics, pets (which have no effect), gear and even Red Beans (real-money currency)! Some people may argue, that it's pay to win, because you can buy good gear with real money, but it can also be obtained by playing the game and as stated before, gear/level isn't everything. You also need skill.Also the launcher is quite notable - it uses none (in the Steam version)! It actually updates itself via the Steam-update-system! There are not many MMOs out there which do that...There is also Open World PvP, but I haven't tried it yet. If requested, I will add few lines about that. The "problem" with it is, that it's not really balanced, so people of level 40 will have a major advantage over low level players, making open world PvP a type of endgame content.Raid bosses are also available at level 40, but since I'm not at that level yet, I can't review those.Overall an exceptional game, with many unique mechanics.The early levels may be kind of boring, but for me it got more fun, the higher level I got.Now for the bad things. The ARES Jobs are all pretty similar and repetitive, consisting of much running around and can be pretty tough at higher levels, if done solo. Also there are some bugs, but I haven't encountered anything game breaking yet.If you dislike repetitive questing/grinding* until you reach the level cap, don't like dynamic events or different/unique gameplay Firefall is most likely not the game for you.*There are many ways to earn experience, but the most consistent and thus fastest for most players are the repetitive ARES Jobs, or instances which will probably get boring if you do them over and overWanna know how fast you can reach the level cap? 50-90 hours, depending on skill, playstyle, solo/group, boosts and such stuff. But after reaching the level cap you still need the perfect gear, of course... and levelling the other 15 frames.The first ten levels will take probably 5 hours10-20 my guess is 10-20 hours20-30 I'd estimate around 20-30 hours30-40 will need 40 or more hoursThese times are assuming that you're new and don't have boosts or anything.P.S: It's probably even faster now, since they increased the spawn rate of dynamic events and rewards for ARES Jobs.If you have newbish questions about the game, there are many guides on Steam. The official forums have some nice information as well (you might also want to visit them to get some addons). And finally there are "mentors" ingame, people who volunteered to help by answering questions. You can spot them by the green leaf in front of their name.Anything I forgot? Want more details on something? Let me know!

content:
3, 2014
												This is a fantastic MMO. I love it. Rather than telling you about abstract qualities however, I'll just give an example of play. So this is what happened to me. I began in a richly detailed and populated city wearing a BattleFrame. I moved over to a terminal and got a mission from the local post-apocalyptic authority to help find a lost girl. I moved over to a glider-pad, was launched into the air and with a sonic-boom was projected forward with wings extended. I glided (under my own direction) down to a ridgeline before arriving at a bug-infested canyon. I proceeded to blast and grenade my way to gory victory by engaging in both horizontal and vertical combat before my ‘operator’ told me to start looking inside the bugs for the girl’s genetic material. Awesome. With no genetic material found (she had not been eaten), I was directed over the hill in search of her SIN ID. That was went I came across another player managing a Thumper (basically a piece of mining equipment). She was holding off scores of bandits trying to steal her stuff. Back to back we fought, dropping goons all around us while exchanging instructions and words of encouragement. Achievement and experience were flashing before us as we looted the looters. Nothing was stolen or claimed and everything was fair. Finally, with a cinematic boost, the Thumper launched into the air and I was rewarded. She thanked me before I continued my mission. I found the lost girl, finally, who had simply run away from home. As the mission was random (or at least I think it was) she happened to be in the middle of a nest. The ground erupted around us and the fighting began, as I struggled to save her. Turns out a convoy was being attacked nearby too so the result was a three-way firefight that got even more complicated when a team of three other players turned up. The gun-play was amazing and everyone had a great time fighting off the staggering number of critters that were involved. That was when I returned to base and began crafting. Let’s just say that the fun continued long after this.The graphics are amazing, the quests are dynamic, the gameplay is solid and the community is supportive. Seriously, buy this game now.

content:
20, 2015
												I started Firefall up for the first time and accidentally spent 6 hours on it. At the lower levels levelling up isn't too much of a grind, especially if you end up wading into a few fights above your level. The game looks good, the environment is interesting and makes you want to explore a bit and so far the 'jobs' or objectives I've been doing have been holding my attention. You get a bit of backstory about the world you're in with most of the jobs, which is nice. You pick up knowledge about the world you're in as you go along.Fighting the chosen (the bad guys) can feel a little overwhelming and frustrating as, if there aren't many players around you can get swamped pretty quickly, but the other players seem happy to get stuck in when they see another player in need, whether is't with a swarm of critters or a platoon of chosen. Decent bit of fun for no cost. Also, you can dance.

in wordpad :Pcurious about the game? i can help u with whether or not to play this!Pros: Firefall---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------1: Amazing landscape and graphics2: Nice Support for old PCs (Dynamic Resolution)3: 5 Playstyles/classes4: New You station (editing your character while ingame)5: Real nice Sci-Fi and Open worlded game6: Various kinds and species of enemies7: Solid tutorial8: Helpfull Co-Op players9: Free to do missions u would like to,sortof10: Free to play (not P2W at all!)11: No annoying operator who repeats things12: Different ways to tackle battles,no battle is the same13: Waypoints,and waypoints can be locked on players/missions    and update most of the time (  only on players)14: Possible to change classes ingame (without creating a new character)15: Able to get Premium currency with ingame currency16: U can make a Squad or Army (Group) to help your friends out easily      also able to TP to the leaders lobby17: After lvl 45,there is content:
1, 2014
												I've been in Firefall for a while. Been interested in it since the infamous presentation at 2011 PAX. Not too long after that, I got in Closed Beta in one of first invitation waves.The game really had potential. Unfortunately, throughout 2012 and 2013 there were some catastrophically bad decisions that were implemented in game. I've completely lost interest in it, so I took a break in 2013 and rarely would check up on it.I've tried it again now that its officialy out, and I've gotta say: I'm amazed. They have completely turned the game around. It finally feels good, the design and mechanics make sense and are fun. It finally feels like it did over 2 years ago, and it feels good.Firefall is definitely one of best F2P games out there at this moment.

												What to say about this... First of all, I am... Sad, truly and deeply sad. I was one of the first 500 in the game, and was a commander tier backer. The 100 dollar tier.I would play this nearly every day before it was even on steam, for many hours. It kept me entertained, kept me coming back... Then, the money nation attacked, of course. Capitalism is a tool for improvement, but when you care too much about the money, and not enough about your product, it becomes the bringer of ruin. The Chosen have won here, men. Humanity has fallen, and our battleframes are all broken. Godspeed you magnificent ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. In retrospect, I had a hell of a lot of fun with this, it was new and interesting when things were still actively being developed, of course. The game had... So, so much promise. So very much promise that it could be something absolutely wonderful, and for a time... It was. Now, however? It's gone. May we find a brighter future for humanity.Commander MalachiteMG signing off. For the last time.

												You know, I haven't played this for too terribly long but here is a first impressions. It is similar to Desiny and Defiance combined. This game has a lot of potential. Thay being said, most of it is just that, potential. You can't go underwater which is disappointing, it feels like there isn't enough loot at all, even trash loot to scavenge or sell, and I don't even think you can just sell it but the salvaging system helps that. Also, you have to build or pay for a one use vehicle that disappears. Considering the distances you travel, it'd be better if it stayed with you. It did a lot of things right though.There is a decent crafting system from what I can tell, the salvaging system seems legit, being able to mine resources is awesome, decent gunplay and adding jetpacks (even if they are lacking) and having such a huge world. Now if only it was filled more with creatures that just roam around.In conclusion, i'd try it, but i wouldn't blame anyone for not liking it

ry 24, 2015
												I played this game back in Alpha and Beta.   To be completely honest i did not find it entertaining fully understanding that it was still being developed.  After a few months of some patches and fixes i got back into it, to see how things were.  It had got a little bit better.  I found myself with nothing to do, this was in early 2014.  So I waited practically a year now and decided to give it a whirl again.  I knew there had been many major updates and over hauls.  From then till now.Then.  I couldnt play it.  Idea was great the game played great, but lacked content and drive.Now.  I cant stop playing.  in the last two weeks just launching from steam i put in 80 hours and loving it.  Thats is not including the non steam hours i put into it.Take backs.Too many complaints about the crafting and resource system made them simplify things.   Major Bummer in my opinion.  The old crafting system was Very Complex and had a strong learning curve.  That particular feature was great.Too many babies that didnt want to put in the effort made them simplify it.  8 year olds can craft now.  In the beginning there were loads of kids playing.  Im talking whiney, moany, suckin on the teets babies.  The Matureaty level for the players was UGH.  Not even joking.  Hated it.But ill tell you what.  Since all the changes Us older folk have been able to appreciate the progress that this game has gone through.  It is very playable and entertaiing now.  All i can simply say is try it.  Its free to play, and if you dont like it you dont have to play it.  put in about 20 hours or so  get a feel for it.  Then make ur decision.

content:
9, 2016
												So Last time I posted a positive review.  You can see it here http://pastebin.com/Apz8Myfd but now I am doing a huge 180 based on highly opinionated reasons.I've played since closed beta and have trudged through the hell that everyone has talked about with optimism.  I can still play the game as is how I have been doing it (which is the wrong way) but that is beside the point.  With the recent sacking of the original developers--multiple times--enough is enough.There is no real point to compare a game from beta to present, especially one that has gone through major changes as much as this one has.  One before official launch, and I can't count the in between because I refuse to do so, and the Devil's Edge update...all fundementally erasing previous gamestyles to the point of re-learning the game.Yes the Beta was great, I'm a huge Tribes 2 fan....that is why I played in the beta.  Over the course of the years, the game became less skill and more easy-to-button-spam kill--which is why with the last recent update I went "screw this, I'm just gonna use the melee weapons they gave us--ps...it was fun to do that.That melee only challenge is still something I can do in this game as is...as a pet project.The truth of the matter is what has happened.  Red5 may have a controversal history that even I don't know much about--nor really care--but the recent event of them all getting sacked is the final straw for me.  I will be optimistic for Red5, but the publishers and multiple developers that keep forcing them to make a game they didn't want has to stop.  This ALMOST happened with my favourite game (Guns of Icarus Online), so I happen to kinda understand the hell developers have with the game and publishers who just want money...Sorry FireFall, you were a great concept, but it's time to finish your grave.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2015
												Note:  I have played this game far more than my steam hours show ( I am surprised it shows any at all since I rarely launch through steam).This game is a flawed and incomplete masterpiece.This is a third person shooter / online rpg that does a great job at making interesting classes, an incredible job of creating a world that feels "alive", and an exceptionally fair f2p model.  You will want to play through the areas again and again with your lower levelled classes, as they are all enjoyable.  The world is overflowing with events, and though standard questing has been added it can be ignored in favor of endless events (thank goodness, because the questing kinda stinks).  I have never felt pressured to spend money, though I have (once, on a good deal for a respawnable glider).  All classes can be unlocked by levelling your other classes, and the in game currency can be exchanged for the premium currency.The game is beautiful, bringing a vibrant outlined look with a sci fi setting that somehow feels right.  Inspirations from the Tribes series are seen in the jetpacks, the art design, and the class design.  The music is similarly beautiful, particularly the ambient synth tracks and the mournful piano melody.  Sound brings the same excellence in quality, though occassional bugs have me hearing an object producing static instead of the intended effect.For the problems, though, which do exist;- the game continues to have bugs.  It is a large game, so it is to be expected, but I feel like they should be worked on some more.- the game used to have very limited content.  This has since been expanded with more events, more zones, the main storyline, and the quest system... but the storyline and quest system kind of stink.  As such you will likely find yourself focusing on doing the event missions over and over, and even though the missions are random and will have different enemies and objectives, they will take place in the same locations.- the grind.  With one of the (many) revamps of the game mechanics, the focus was changed from crafting focus to levelling focus.  To get the most out of your frame, you will need to level up several frames.  Right now it seems to me like the perks you get for levelling frames are not so powerful as to force you to level them all, but are still coming off as rewarding.  Others may feel differently.- slow updates.  The game does not seem to have enough people working on it to pump out updates at the pace of.. pretty much any other game.  I assume this is because of their overly generous f2p model, which basically lets people have the game without spending a cent.  Maybe I will stop being part of the problem and spend a little more on it.- finally, it must be said that the developers of this game have completely revamped the game many times.  Now that they consider the game "released" I do think it is less likely that we will see another complete rework of the game, but it is worth noting that there have been some extreme changes several times since the game became playable.To wrap it up, this is an amazing game that I think must be played.  It is the type of game that you fall in love with and then end up resenting for not being as incredible as it could have been.  Just do not forget that it is still pretty incredible even with the shortfalls it has.  If you ever thought Tribes would make a good PvE game, or thought that a shooter could make a good MMO, you need to try this game.  If you just like co op, you should try this game.  If you like open worlds with tons of events, you should try this game.  Really, give it a shot already, the whole thing is free.

ber 8, 2016
UPDATEAs of November 29th, 2016, Firefall's FIRST mission and every mission up to level 34, has been offline for OVER 60 days!The business practices in the last month by the parent company, The9, have been deceptive, deceitful, and, as far as the Rhode Island Attorney General's office is concerned, is illegal.  Widely known and in news sites everywhere, Red5 employees have all been laid off as of July, minus 2 employees, who no longer reside in the USA but hold the title of Red5 employee's for deceptive purposes, explained later..  The company still operates the game while allowing unknowing customers to purchase Red Beans, who are in fact not receiving what they purchased, with NO form of support because the support section of there website has been offline for quite some time, and of course Valve wont step in.  The website has no recent information or any information stating the details of the games future as a PC game here on Steam or any public news about the Red Bean/Support section issue.  For the last week and a half, the games server has been on and off many times a day and so have the websites operated by Red5/The9.  These issues expand to users not being able to activate missions or field jobs and is not operational minus being able to walk around the maps.  While all these issues have been occuring, the supposed Red5 employees have been coming onto the game and the forum telling players they are "fixing" things yet its obvious nothing has been done and things have only gotten worse. The game was removed from Steam recently but had returned 4-5 days later.  This should NOT have happened unless who ever is managing the game contacted Valve, which is an extremely deceitful move in itself. ry 28
												TL;DR: Firefall was once a great great game, still have some great 3d combat mechanics with the jetpacks and dinamic fights, but since the launch been suffering and right now is slowly dying with a incomplete story and no dev team working on it.Played this game a lot during the beta, awesome, wasn't really a story wasn't a problem, it was pretty awesome and dinamic combat mechanics, crafting and resources mechanics too ("thumping" or using giantic drill to mine the ground after resources and defend that machinary till the "thumping" end was one of the main mechanics and really fun to do, while rewarding too as you would use those resources to craft new better gear), the game was just incredible to play with friends no matter how simple some aspects would be.It wad a really really long beta (years), with more than a few changes since the start, right on the launch a lot of the game was changed a LOT, more like modern MMORPG, same cenario and story based on it, not bad, but pretty diferent and weird to play after being used to the old way, went away for a long time and about 2-3 years after tried again for missing the dinamic combat and the fun of thumping. I went back and played for a few months before getting bored and dropign it.The combat is still pretty fun, dinamic and awesome, and the storyline isn't great but it's good enough (for while it last, somewere on the way to the end at mid of the last map avaible now, the story mission just stop and leave you hanging with a lot of just presented and unanswer questions around), mostly sad the crafting is gone right now, with a promisse of getting back maybe in the future, but leaving getting gear limited to doing the side repetable (random) missions and daily stuff, what also made thumping pretty useless except for getting fast exp, as right now it only give money instead of resources. So around the end the game become just grind for gear and level other classes running around doing "dinamic events" like stuff or repetable missions, the only real endgame being 2 or 3 raids and time to time some big event that as far as I've seen and hear from other people playing for longer usualy break and stop happening for weeks till the devs fix it.As a side short info about the dev studio, Red 5 was once a great studio with great ideas, the beta went between hell and heaven cause their old kinda crazy (not in a good way) lead, but they someway worked hard to make things work and the game be great. As I could dig later when I started playing again, somewere between that moment and now almost all of the original staff were fired or leaved Red 5, and last year all Red 5 dev team was been fired with no one being on it since.

content:
ry 25, 2015
												TL;DR and Pros and Cons at bottom.Firefall is an interesting and diverse take on the FPSMMO genre of games, allowing a player to take on many different roles, and exploring team dynamics in a way very few other games have mastered. Each squad member will find themselves useful and needed at one point or another because of something that only they can do, and that's one of the things that makes Firefall a beautifully executed game. However, it's certainly not without it's faults. There are several instances where the game will become a long stretch of repetitive mission grinding, or thumping for resources. It can be excruciatingly annoying when you have to grind just to level up your character, doing missions that are essentially 'go here, press e, go there, kill these guys, etc.' The game does redeem itself however. Some of these missions you find at ARES job boards actually have fairly interesting stories and characters interwoven into them, making the repetitveness worth it. For example, a job at Sunken Harbor had me laughing quite a bit at a character known as the Meddler. Her personality was so over-the-top ridiculous, that it was hard to NOT love her. In addition to the job boards, the game builds upon the story through campaign missions which can be played at any time, so long as you meet the minimum level requirements. Some of these campaign missions will have you traveling into dangerous territory in order to save a crashed dropship pilot. Others will have you escorting a cart carrying broken equipment. Even more will pit you against seemingly endless waves of enemies as you desperately try to keep your foothold in their territory. That's what makes Firefall beautiful. It's an incredible experience, and I highly recommend you jump into this enthralling universe.TL;DR // PROS AND CONS:Firefall is a very different take on the FPSMMO genre of games, and is well worth your time.PROS:Massive worldGreat graphicsPlethora of random eventsDiverse classes allowing for incredible team dynamicsTons of weaponsPlayer-driven economy system via the in-game MarketplaceOtherwise, ridiculously funCONS:Can be extremely grindyMissions found on Job Boards tend to be repetitiveSomewhat steep learning curveOVERALL RATING: 9.5/10

content:
ber 22, 2014
												Firefall has fallen into the category of games that... Bring me back to what the word "Fun" means. Many modern titles try to push quest lines, and stuff like that. Firefall has a decent questline, but it isn't what truly brings me towards it. It's the sheer amount of random, silly, dumb, stupid, but amazing things you can do with your time. It's both entertaining as a system to work with, through jobs, events, and thumping. When I'm not doing that, I'm trying to explore, and climb the tallest structure near me. The best game in my opinion, is the game in which you are so unrestricted in your choices, that you can play your own games within the game. The last game I've played that was this entertaining was Halo 3. Some people might look at me as if I were crazy for saying that, but Halo 3 in it's day, you didn't have to play the game as the game itself. Matchmaking was mediocre at best, and the storyline was short. But the Foundry, the Custom Games options, and the fact you and a couple of friends could do what you set your hearts out to on your own, made it worth every weekend night I spent making memories.Firefall gives me that precise feeling, all over again. It's a great game. I hope whoever reads this review will give it a try, and if they do, don't try to play it as though it were a conventional quest-driven MMO. It isn't. It's whatever you, and a couple of your buddies want to make it be.5/5

content:
11, 2014
												I initially played Firefall because I was intrigued by its premise...but I was unfortunately unamused by the execution.  Standard gameplay largely consists of being tasked to go to a place, shoot at things, then go to other places to shoot at things until you return to the place you started.  Often these tasks consist of multiple jaunts of 400+ meters of travel and all this running quickly becomes dull even with the jetpack your character is supplied with (The jets are primarily for upward mobility rather than lateral movement).  While there do exist ways to expedite the time involved in travel by way of gliders and temporary vehicles (With, as I understand it, permanent vehicles available at level 25?  Apologies if I'm wrong in this regard as I was unable to keep motivated to play to that point).I personally experienced combat as the Engineer frame and was rather unimpressed with it overall.  The frame's primary weapon is a dual purpose beam weapon that can damage enemies or repair friendly structures, but I found myself having to expend 60% or more of my weapon's ammunition on targets on a fairly consistent basis in spite of receiving weapon upgrades at a fairly decent pace.  This was made more unfortunate by the fact that you can only carry a maximum of four full reloads for your primary weapon and this led to me mainly using my secondary weapon.  The engineer frame starts out with a shotgun as a secondary and I just found the weapon outright appalling.  I found that I had to pretty much be point blank and dead center on a target to deal a worthwhile amount of damage to any enemy.  Later I switched to using an SMG as a secondary weapon.  It had better accuracy at range but I quickly found myself having to reload its 65 round magazine multiple times to deal with enemies of equal level using an SMG that was of my level.  The saving grace to these secondary weapons is that your ammunition for them is infinite...but in practice they seem to be rather weak in utility.I can't speak for later game but the game rather quickly lost my interest early in, and if a game cannot hold interest through the early stages that speaks of a considerable flaw with it as a whole.  As it stands now I cannot recommend that you spend a considerable amount of time playing Firefall, though if you simply have some time to kill and space on your hard drive you could do far worse.If nothing else, give the game a few months to get on its feet before making any real investments on it.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
5, 2014
												Very, Very buggy. Glitches that sometimes prevent you from advancing further in the mission, major graphical glitches and Pay 2 Win. The community can be helpful at times but it is extremely fanboyish, even if you point out a bug they instantly turn hostileCrafting is complex and a pain, by the time you get the needed supplies for a item you have researched (crafting is in 4 stages, collecting raw materials, Refining, Researching Then Manufacturing said item) you have already passed the level where it becomes useful.The Marketplace is also overly complex and not helpful, there is no tutorial to help you for it and it goes something like this; To sell an item you need to create a sell order for said item so someone can pick the order up and purchase the item for credits (the player currency) or you could fill in a buy order where the person who wants to buy something puts in a order for someone selling to fill it (no one ever creates legitimate buy orders that is not spam like 500 of 1 item for 1 credit)There is no fast way to travel early in game unless you want to spend some money IRL to buy a permenant vehicle so the only way you can travel without reaching level 25 (which takes roughly 30 hours of pure gameplay for a new player) or using 1 use, bad vehicles which you have a chance to get from slot machines is to buy one of the games packages for XX amount of 'Red Beans' which is a currency you buy with real money to purchase just about anything, even advanced versions of the default classes for 100 beans each, which of course, is a rip off.You can convert Crystite (a material you get from refining, killing, doing missions etc etc but you use for crafting) into credits for 1:25 which is only useful to use in end game when you are making too much Crystite or have no use for it as you have researched everything you need. However there is a conversion max you can do each day (i believe it is 1000 however im not sure) and the same you can do for Red Beans however it is much more credits to convert for a single Red Bean.You can buy 'pilots licenses' from the marketplace which gives you access to the advanced classes that you can purchase with credits however it costs roughly 2000 credits for a single license on average as they do fluctuate which adds up to roughly 50,000 Crystite!Please note this review is not complete and I did not have sufficent time to complete it all in one sitting, I will add more to it in further detail at a later date

content:
6, 2014
												Fun yet boring...The game is setup pretty well at first glance. Good environment, good background story, nice praphics and a very good soundtrack. And when you start playing for your first couple of hours the game feels very good as well and seems to be a lto ot fun. That is until you've played a while, have hit level 15 or so and see the repeting of missions starting.Firefall uses 'Job Board's to give you missions. Sadly the number of different missions is pretty limited. This results in missions starting to repeat themself, though not literally, but you will see the same kind of objective on new places and an other sugarcoat around it.Skills and progression is an issue as well. You only have 4 skills and at level 8 you alreayd have them all. At that point you'll only be working on upgrading the skills itself. Either through research & crafting or by grinding vouchers to buy them from NPCs. Research & crafting really takes forever, while vouchers drop you back in the repeatative mission grind.On a positive note, the cash shop is not Pay2Win. There are no game breaking items in there, and you can obtain the cash shop currency (Red Beans) from in-game grinding. With that, cash shop items are tradeble, and you can find almost everything from it on the auction house.
