content:
11, 2014
												I have played Firefall Since first day of open beta. Saw alot of changes, good and bad ones. But recently i decided to check on release and i was totally dissapointed. So, if you liked complex old crafting system and good rewarding thumping in pockets - then move along. Nothing for you there. So here's my impression and feedback.- Game became alot more friendly to new players, also alot more easier- Crafting got simplified as maximum as possible. You don't need to worry abough energy, weight and stats. You just craft pre-defined items every time.- Thumping now can be done blindfolded. Resource veins is a total mess - there is a huge lack of resource quantity. So thumping is a pain now really.- Battlframes. Have levels now - takes ages to grind. Gear got simplified as well. No more servos, jumpjets and platings. Just core and weapons. Also repair pools are gone and now gear is permanent and can't broke. You can repair it as much as you like. Right now you just grind the best gear and that's it.Missions. New field missions are just the same as ARES just another name. Slight imprivement tho - voiced dialogs and some kind of a story. Still boring.- Currency and Market. Biggest con for me. New currency been added - credits. Once per 24 hours you can exchange 25k CY for 1k credits. Now you need credits for everything. Prices are rediclous. White metal and purple metal costs the same. Very frustrating to use. Crystite became almost useless.Again - just my opiniion and impressions as old player. Right now alot of things are broken\not working as intended\missing or w\e. Some changes are just weird\stupid. Honestly after i played for a bit i just feel that i don't have any desire to log in back. I know things most likely gonna change. I loved this game, really. And i don't want to bash it but this just plain redicilous.You still feel free to try.

												This game used to be fun, circa 2014.  Now, it's just a mess of a game that has gone in a very strange direction.  It's almost like the Devs can see the inevitable sinking and are just purposely blowing the ballast on it so that it goes under and they can move on to other projects that much faster.The newest overhaul just didn't make any sense.  I logged in after not having played for awhile and was completely lost.  Where did my lvl 40 frames go?  Where were my resources?  What is happening?Play it because it's free, but I wouldn't spend money on it.  Firefall is the Titanic, and the latest major update was the iceberg.  It's taking on water fast.

content:
ber 22, 2014
												Firefall has fallen into the category of games that... Bring me back to what the word "Fun" means. Many modern titles try to push quest lines, and stuff like that. Firefall has a decent questline, but it isn't what truly brings me towards it. It's the sheer amount of random, silly, dumb, stupid, but amazing things you can do with your time. It's both entertaining as a system to work with, through jobs, events, and thumping. When I'm not doing that, I'm trying to explore, and climb the tallest structure near me. The best game in my opinion, is the game in which you are so unrestricted in your choices, that you can play your own games within the game. The last game I've played that was this entertaining was Halo 3. Some people might look at me as if I were crazy for saying that, but Halo 3 in it's day, you didn't have to play the game as the game itself. Matchmaking was mediocre at best, and the storyline was short. But the Foundry, the Custom Games options, and the fact you and a couple of friends could do what you set your hearts out to on your own, made it worth every weekend night I spent making memories.Firefall gives me that precise feeling, all over again. It's a great game. I hope whoever reads this review will give it a try, and if they do, don't try to play it as though it were a conventional quest-driven MMO. It isn't. It's whatever you, and a couple of your buddies want to make it be.5/5

content:
11, 2014
												I have played Firefall Since first day of open beta. Saw alot of changes, good and bad ones. But recently i decided to check on release and i was totally dissapointed. So, if you liked complex old crafting system and good rewarding thumping in pockets - then move along. Nothing for you there. So here's my impression and feedback.- Game became alot more friendly to new players, also alot more easier- Crafting got simplified as maximum as possible. You don't need to worry abough energy, weight and stats. You just craft pre-defined items every time.- Thumping now can be done blindfolded. Resource veins is a total mess - there is a huge lack of resource quantity. So thumping is a pain now really.- Battlframes. Have levels now - takes ages to grind. Gear got simplified as well. No more servos, jumpjets and platings. Just core and weapons. Also repair pools are gone and now gear is permanent and can't broke. You can repair it as much as you like. Right now you just grind the best gear and that's it.Missions. New field missions are just the same as ARES just another name. Slight imprivement tho - voiced dialogs and some kind of a story. Still boring.- Currency and Market. Biggest con for me. New currency been added - credits. Once per 24 hours you can exchange 25k CY for 1k credits. Now you need credits for everything. Prices are rediclous. White metal and purple metal costs the same. Very frustrating to use. Crystite became almost useless.Again - just my opiniion and impressions as old player. Right now alot of things are broken\not working as intended\missing or w\e. Some changes are just weird\stupid. Honestly after i played for a bit i just feel that i don't have any desire to log in back. I know things most likely gonna change. I loved this game, really. And i don't want to bash it but this just plain redicilous.You still feel free to try.

content:
er 9, 2014
												Im not to far into the game yet, not even lvl 20. However this game seems pretty freak'n awsome...First off im really glad to see an mmo move in a fresh new direction, i'm also glad to see the shooter genre being worked with in a new light. These two very popular game catagories havent seemed to chage much at all since mmos like Guild Wars 2 and the more recent Tera Rising which unfortunatly lacks a little depth. Even less evoulution has come from FPS (first person shooters) and 3PS (third person shooters). I have yet to play Destiny so i cannot comment on how it may have changed the shooter genre, but i have played a wonderfull 3ps mmo called Global agenda and let me tell you, was that game fun. Global agneda died out quite awhile ago it seems, even with rumor for a remake. But from what i have experienced so far, Firefall gives a very similar feeling to Global Agenda.To be honest i was first sceptical of the MMOFPS Firefall. The screen shots depicted bulky looking character models and an impression of just another delevoper failing to reimagine the mmo genre -I was wrong. It started on a night like most, I was dwindling on steam browsing for a new mmo to play, because for some reason i just couldent get back into playing WoW. I decided, hey what have i got to lose by atleast trying this new game? ahhh but first let me check youtube. And wow nothing but beople complaining aobut things like the inability to pick up multiple quests and finish them all at once and even more so about how long the game took to get out of beta. Sifting through all the hate i realized that DIFFERENT is exactly what i was looking fore. I have come to absolutly love that i can only do one quest or "job" at a time in Firefall it makes the game feel more real and immersive for me. Each Job has new and unique fully voiced dialog with multiple characters and a suprisingly intricate story depth (per mission, or town set of missions). However there arent too many to do per town, city, station, or whatever you like to call it, this is totaly OK! because there are things happening all over the map, that in most cases can be joined at any time without the need to group or even started on your own to take on the challenge of soloing the game. Oh, and might i add all of these random occuring events are also fully voiced and do a good job at making you feel like you are a high tech, bad ♥♥♥ space cowboy.All in all what i mean to say is i like the direction this game is going. Fire fall gives all the feelings of both an mmo and a console game, the artwork and graphics are beautifle while not needing immense power to support them, and the questing/ PVE of this MMOFPS  has kept me entertained more than any other MMORPG with the exeptions of GW2 and WoW wich i rarely play either of the two any more. As far as PVP goes i am reluctant to say i can not yet report, i can say however, i cant wait to hit lvl 40 and run off into that open world, no rules, anything goes pvp island i have heared about.P.S. Could someone please explain to me how this game is completely free? im entirely baffeld at how such a nice game requires no money to play. I understand Firefall uses a type of micropayment like LoL's methods, but LoL has a very lage user base buying things like skins and wards. Firefall doesent seem to have an extencive list of really cool stuff to buy.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2015
												I always find it funny when people say "all you do is shoot stuff" and give it a bad review, ITS A SHOOTING GAME WHAT DO YOU EXPECT!!! they obviously did not play it long enough to experence the great squad system the massive world battles/events IE:Giant monsters (Brontadon King aka: BK)Massive buildings being overrun and need liberatingWatchtower takeoversMelding TornadosSpecial Monsters you have to find and kill5 massive areasGiant end game bossesThumping for itemsthe list goes on.................. I found Firefall to be a great new fresh approach to the MMO/FPS titles, I have over 270 hours in the game and have not spent £1 so far I have 5 level 40 battleframes all with good to decent gear, the game is a grind sure but thats the point of MMO's right? coampred to other MMO's this game throws exp at you, try playing FFXI FFIV WOW or Rift and see how much of a grind they are ,you get NO exp loss when you die only damage to your battleframe that you can repair in 20 seconds, you can get to level 10 in about 1 hour on any of the basic frames with no need to spend any real money ingame unless you want to "support" the devs (something I have yet to do/decide) great ingame community, looks amazing,plays really well,great crafting system and perks, massive world events and varied terrains with lots of places to explore and easy map leveling system to follow for the beginner there is NOTHING hidden behind ingame pay walls to stop you from getting to the top level of 40 and end game content.You can get the Redbeans for free by converting crystite into credits and then credits into redbeans(crystite is dropped by all mobs in game)Currently:25.000 of crystite gives you 1000 credits109 credits gives you 1 redbeanIf you play for long enough (say a couple of hours a day, like I do) after 3 weeks you will have enough redbeans to buy some decent in game items faster bikes, re-usable jump pads, battleframe colors ect all for free.

content:
, 2016
												Oh man, where do I start?  IN CASE YOU DON'T WANT TO READ:
IF YOU'RE A RETURNING VETERAN: DON'T GET IT
IF YOU'RE A NEW PLAYER: DON'T GET IT  A long long time ago, I was bored, and as was the will of the Internet, I happened to stumble apon a closed-beta version of a game called Firefall. Now, this was cool as all hell, and I scraped together $20 to buy a founder pack and make my way into the game. After the tutorial, the world was yours to explore. Of course, there were side and story missions, which I chose to partake in.Cut to a couple years later, a slightly more cooler me, browsing the Steam Free to Play section. It has been long since the Age of Firefall, when I played almost every day. I had moved on, mostly because I didn't have anyone that I knew personally to play with.Then, while browsing, my heart soars, tears well, as I have just stumbled on to Firefall(again). My boredom meter dropped instantly down to -100, and I began downloading the game through Steam. I grab my besterest friend and slammed him into the bandwagon, and then we were offered a few blessed years of happiness and prosperity(I almost said peace, but then again  someone  had to be on the end of our guns).Then... at our peak, we were slaughtered. Update 1.5 had just released, and so had the demons. The changes were acceptable at first. Ninja swords as melee weapons? SURE! Portable health packs? WHY THE ♥♥♥♥ NOT? However, in this case the bad outweighed the good. Bugs, new, complex systems(that were NOT user-friendly), the revocation of our most loved battleframes, only to be tempted by XP or a new frame, and all around generic MMO trash surrounded us. They beat us down to a pulp, chewed us up and spit us out. Now the Age of Fire has long been extinguished, and Firefall is now nothing but a conduit for nothing but evil and bland MMO elements.  There is salvation, fortunately, because where there is evil, there are heroes are willing to combat it!  https://www.change.org/p/crixa-labs-make-ember-a-spiritual-successor-to-firefall?recruiter=562901777 BEFORE I FORGET,  This hero  used #MakeFirefallGreatAgain in their review and I literally could not finish this without using it so thanks for that, uh, also I stole the link from his review, so again, yea thanks bro(its a noble cause though)

												I have fond memories of this game in the past, and returning after an extended absence I could not control excited me greatly. Little did I realize that I was setting myself up for an equally massive letdown.1. My character class is now effectively worthless in PVE after a blatantly unfair patch.2. A lot of my items were replaced with vastly inferior gear.3. The crafting system is offline.4. The servers are very unstable.5. Character classes I was eligible to unlock thanks to a previous purchase are now locked.6. Support is impossible to contact due to website downtime and website errors.7. I can't even file a bug crash without getting a fatal error on the bug reporter app that pops up after a crash.8. A lot of content was cut instead of fixed and it shows.9. Many achievements are now completely impossible to obtain.Just don't bother. I'll be forced to remove the game from my library in the end. I'd rather lose this game quickly then suffer hoping that it will be repaired and rebalanced. For a player who actually paid for some of the content in the past that is now missing, this leaves a rancid taste in my mouth and I must now brush my teeth an additional time for the night.

content:
13, 2014
												I played the game in beta, but I took a long break, and only recently came back to play it on release. I never got too attached to a specific build of the game, but I did play enough hours to wrap my head around it.On paper, it sounds like a good idea. Marry shooter mechanics with some MMO questing and skill progression, and you'll have people coming in droves!In practice, it's got some shooter chops to form the foundation of a game. Each basic class gets a different kind of primary weapon, and your choice of secondary gives you a bit more room to play with. But the MMO half of the experience is so threadbare, and feels so soulless, that I was always aware I was grinding. Grinding for weapons, grinding for gear, grinding for cosmetic unlocks, grinding for a blue version of the EXACT SAME green item I already had!And I had enough. I never did hit high level content on the release build (got to about level 20 with my subclass frame), but what I played was such a sucking void in my time spent that I couldn't help but put the mouse down at the end of a session and ask myself..."WHY? Why did I just do that for two hours?"Some people might consider games in general (and grind-heavy MMOs in particular) to be nothing more than a time sink. But  in other cases, there's something to maintain a player's interest, whether it's the world, the lore, the art, or even a player class that just hits all the right buttons in your brain.Ultimately, with Firefall, you get all of the illusion of MMO progression, and none of the distinctiveness and originality that you might get in an actual MMO. And frankly, if you're at that point, wouldn't you rather just be playing a plain shooter?

content:
5, 2014
												           5 Thing About Fire-Fall that are obviously annoying or1.This game gets VERY repeditive, all you do is go out and kill things, escort people, gather supplies, fight off enemies while protecting a point, trying to find missing people, and pest controll.2. Your parter that calls you boss all the time and has an odd mixed accent that you can never tell where she got it from, just from her talking all the time on every mission gets mildly annoying and repeditive, half the time i swear they took words she said and put them into a sentence then make it sound like she actually said that through editing.3. ALL and i mean ALL of the boy npc are based off the same base modle, it is painfully obvious.4. For the first 15 or so levels all you fight are ahrenas, sculvers, hissers, giant flying bugs, and bandits. The bandits seem to be over powered compaired to the normal sculvers and ahrenas, at the lower level mission to kill black forest gang members they can kill you very easily without having to put up a fight.5. Now this one might not be as bad as i may put it out to be but Free to Play MY ♥♥♥. As you progress you see other players with cool colors and armor and vehicles, but to get that you need what Red 5tm calls red beans witch is in game premium curency to buy things with, like a Rocket powered motor-cycle that costs 175 red beans witch equaits to roughly 25 dollars (USD). Now for the armor color, The colors and patterns are pretty cool not gonna lie, but you only get 3 free base color cobonations when you start the game they include, a completely white suit, brown with green accents, and a lvery light blue with different shades of that same blue all over it. Now your wondering about other colors and patterns, well they all cost up to 50-75 red beans that roughly equaits to 10-15 dollors (USD) each. They also have head gear, hiar/facial hair , classes, weapns and armor, all at rediciously high prices EXAMPLE. head gear 50-100red beans (depending) , hair/facial hair red beans 50-75 (depending) , classes 200-300---> 45-60(USD) red beans (depending), weapons and armor 75-100 red beans.This hopfully shows that the cool things you see in game all come at a price you probably wont be willing to pay.         I respect your own opinions about this game, but i stand by the fact that it is a very kill, kill ,grind ,grind, uniform sloppily put together type of game and you would need to put a ♥♥♥♥ ton of time and effort into the game to get to your overall goals or get very far.

content:
10, 2014
												The good: this game had (and perhaps still has) potential.  The gameplay is intended to be fluid and fairly rapidly-paced.  The questing (other than campaign quests) is fairly 'lite' on the story and I enjoyed the possibility of 'leveling' the same character in different roles in a way that made sense.  Red 5s stance on cheating is delightfully straighforward.  There are plentiful simple semi-randomized quests with middling rewards.The bad:  There were several quests I could not finish due to bugs.  There was a quest with a node in 'deep water' (think damage zones) which, once you used, you took damage until you died (which then teleported me two zones away to a different respawn point).  There were two quests that sat at "loading next waypoint" (or the equivalent, I forget the exact wording) the quest wouldn't progress, and relogging cleared the quest from your active quests.  Finally, as Acidule mentioned in his review, the tuning for enemy advancement is rather awkward.  You usually fight packs of 3-12 mooks at a time, and a large pack of equal-level ones will kill you.  I feel like if their net code was better, this would be less of an issue.  (I run off broadband with sub 15ms ping and 90/25 mb bandwidth so there is no shortage on my end).  A further point brought up in another review is the decidedly monetized feel for a lot of what I would consider fairly basic things.  Inventory isn't an issue at relatively low level (although with all the different crafting materiels I could see it becoming one) but purchasing more slots requires use of the cash currency.  As do most of the permanent travel options.  I wouldn't have expected the vehicles to be such a big issue, however there is *SO MUCH RUNNING* needed that I can only feel they are trying to perform the same "2nd-class citizen" action that has ruined the appeal of so many other F2P games.  There is a big difference between "freemium" games where you get either cosmetic or minor benefits and ones that feel 'gated' by the payment requirements.Bottom line, if this game was still listed as being in beta, I could be much more forgiving of the flaws and bugs.  I may give it another shot in a few weeks or months to see if there are any improvements or fixes... Then again, with all the various MMOs and other F2P games to play, I might not.

content:
0, 2014
												A solid game with its up and downs. It went through a developer hell (you can research if you want to know) to arrive at its current state.You are an ARES agent equpped with a battleframe. There are 5 classes of frames each with 2-3 advanced subclasses. Assault, Dreadnaught, Engineer, Recon & Biotech are the basic ones available right away. To unlock an advanced sub-class frame you need to level any already unlocked frame to 40. Alternatively, you can just buy a pilot license with cash or purchase one off the player market. The latter method involves a decent amount of grinding as in-game currency is harder to come by than usual.The game game certainly has its charm - the colourful world, a few interesting personalities, fresh combat. But all of that is balanced out by the monotony of grind once the initial novelty passes, the somewhat boring crafting system and a rudimentary player economy.While the release version is quite OK there are some things that turned to worse since closed beta. The game's resource and crafting system went through many iterations, some more in-depth than the others. At present you can only boost any one base stat of your frame with mutually exclusive 'cores'. I see this as a huge step back as before you were able to boost most stats by crafting better battleframe components. Jumpjets allowed you to have a better, faster boost, plating gave you armour and health/regen, servos were responsible for run/sprint speed and jump height and so on. Weapon and other gear crafting has gone through some dramatic changes as well. As the game is right now, crafting anything except the highest tier gear is pointless as you'd have to grind for resources and, chances are, you'll sooner get an item drop comparable to the one you're looking to craft.If you want a few hours of fun the game will deliver, but beyond that it turns into a grind-fest to get to end-game of which there is very little. Keep an eye out for future content updates. Hopefully, those will improve and expand Firefall.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
0, 2014
												Just want to point out I've been playing since 2012 and steam hours are just from the steam client.Whatever you do don't use the steam client. For some reason it is filled with more bugs than the client from the actual website.Firefall wise, this game is pretty awesome. I feel bad for the new players though because you only get to choose one battleframe and you can't change unless you pay money or get it to level 40.  In the beta you started out with all the accord frames and had to unlock the others.Gameplay wise it is fun, you can switch between first person and third person, glide around, grind resources, quest, craft, get pets, and play different classes. The crafting system is intense and requires you to "thump" for resources.Thumping is basically an auto mine feature where you guard the thumping device from constant waves of enemies that get harder and harder the longer you "thump" or mine for resources. This is what you will be doing for a really big portion of the game. The only downside to this is that it can get really redundant and boring. Just take a break and do something else and go back to it!You can also join other players in thumping and recieve a portion of the resources they are thumping. The bigger the thumper the harder it will be to defend it. It doesn't take away from what the owner of the thumper recieves so dont be afraid to hop in and help. Free xp and resources! Can't complain.The red beans are the cash shop of the game. Pretty well balanced in my opinion, I think the battleframes are a little pricey at around 15 dollars per frame. Each frame cost 100 beans (or get a frame to level 40). 50 bucks will get you 4 frames (450 red beans) because you get bonus beans for buying in bulk so obviously the more beans you buy the cheaper the frame.  If thats all you buy then basically you have bought yourself a game anyways so do your research and pick 4 frames to love. Or just get frames to level 40 and unlock them yourself.All in all it is fully free to play, no pay to win, fun, and DON'T GET THE STEAM CLIENT! GET IT FROM THE FIREFALL WEBSTSITE!

												This game is pretty good. I will have the CONS & PROS in detail.I'll try to update this when I can. For now it'll be recommended to try.PROS-Storyline is pretty good if you pay attention to it. (Though I haven't for various reasons)-The world is amazingly set up. The world is by far, the most unique world I've seen in any game.-Questing is actually fairly good. You don't have to stay in the same area that long if you don't wish too. (That I've experienced)-You can create an Army (Clan/Guild).-Graphics are amazing. (Usually I don't look at the games graphics, but I must compliment this one.)-You can actually move & resize some of the interface components. -You can customize the character camera and more. (Moving the 3rd Person FOV.)-Can switch from 3rd Person to First Person at anytime.CONS-Limited character customization. (Though I'm sure they're working on it, but for now this will stay in the cons.)-Grinding can become repetitive. (But it is fairly interesting because of the setting.)-Armies don't have much for customization. (Ranks, Permissions, Etc. I do suppose they may be working on this but for now it'll stay in the cons.)-Is computer intensive at times.-Graphics glitch out when using ALT + TAB. (Best to run in windowed if you plan to multitask otherwise everything will turn black.)-Interface needs some work. (Primarily more options to customize. (Can't resize/move Minimap, or the Main Bar.)

content:
1, 2015
												Hi-Just wanted to throw in my two cents.  If you like Borderlands or other FPSs, this is well worth a try.  It's truly free-to-play; you can play this indefinitely without paying a cent- you will not reach a point that you have to cough up money for.  Leveling will take you a bit longer without buying VIP membership (which boosts XP and some other things), but it's not all that big of a deal.  I have friends that have played for over 100 hours without buying anything.  Plus, you can buy the vast majority of items with in-game money if you want to put the time in.The big draw for this is the fun of leveling different classes, and developing gear.  There is more end-game stuff to do than in Borderlands, for instance.  Don't get me wrong... the BL franchise is my favorite by far, but you reach a point where you have everything and have done everything.  I found that in FF, there is always something to do, if you adjust yourself to wanting to do it.  If you can find a few buddies or join a squad/ army, the possibilities increase.  The MMO feature allows you to meet new players, if you want to, and go from there.I've read the negative reviews, and most of them seem to come from disappointed beta players.  I came to the game just after official release, so I can't really speak to what is was like and what may or may not have changed.  There is a grinding aspect to the leveling, but more so because there are 16 frames to level up, if you want.  However, it's no more grindy than BL, with the increasing level caps and having to repeat Vault Hunter modes several times.So, I'd strongly recommend giving this a try.  I continue to be surprised that more people haven't tried it, but I suspect it's because of suspicion about the MMO feature.  I felt the same way, but I gave it a try.  What game have you played that you can play for a year or more and still find fun things to do in it?GraniteHead1

content:
9, 2014
												So far I’ve played this for a hour and a half or so. It’s good for what it is, but it’s not my thing.


YouTube™ Video: Firefall - part 1 (first impressions) 

			Views: 93		

			This game is Firefall by Red5 Studio. Enjoy. I also posted my review on steam. You can read it here - http://steamcommunity.com/id/SatanovichZ1/recommended/227700		

I didn’t really know anything about this game before today. So I wasn’t sure what to expect. When it said FPS MMO I thought maybe that would mean it’s sort of like Planetside. But it’s not like that, so far it feels like a cross between WOW and borderlands. Gameplay is primarily PVE. I’ve pretty much only played solo so far. I mainly found myself taking one quest, travelling to a location, killing a set number of hostile aliens, picking up an item and returning to the quest giver. Unfortunately for me after having played WOW and borderlands before it felt very ‘been there, done that’. Especially with having to travel by foot to objectives, why would I want simulate walking? But it still feels better than what I remember WOW being like which is the main MMORPG that I’ve played. I really wanted to just to get stuck into some team PVE instances or PVP matches. I did participate in what I think was a matchmade coop PVE instance. But I didn’t have a lot of time to look at that today which sucks, because it actually started to get interested once I reached that. There is supposed to be PVP as well but I didn’t have a chance to experience that today. After a little bit of research I found how you’re supposed to add yourself to the queue for that but it didn’t work for me. And I haven’t found any information about when you are able to do that. I can only assume that I need to progress further in order to unlock PVP matchmaking. One feature that I did like in this was the jetpack ability, that’s a cool if limited way to move around.Initially I felt that the graphics were actually below what I expected. I felt maybe the textures weren’t that detailed. I really got sense that the game is geared towards being able to support action on a large scale i.e. large scale battles with a large amount of players. But actually after playing it for a while I felt that the graphics aren’t bad at all. The cutscenes and dialogue in the beginning I didn’t really pay a lot of attention to because I really just wanted to get stuck into the game. So I can’t really say much about the lore and the storyWhat are you getting with this game. It’s sort of a Borderlands like experience that costs nothing. If you really like MMORPG games this might be right for you. At this stage I don’t know how restricted you are in the long run as non-paying player. But hopefully you are not put at an extreme disadvantage if you don’t invest money into the game. I would have liked to have just been able to engage in PVP combat right from start. If I get around to it I want to do more on PVE instances and PVP matches in this game hopefully do a let’s play on it/add more to my review. That’s all I have to say about this game for today.Click here for my YouTube gaming channel

												In short: Customize your frames, craft your own weapons and burn arachnas.+ 10 points for jetpacks, controls are very intuitive and fun.Been playing this for almost 3 years. Perfect for casual play. There's some grind as in any game of this kind but the difference is FF's grind is not mindless.The world is dynamic, events pop around all the time, there's always something to do and the devs are pumping more content regularly.It has bugs, and the servers are wonky occasionally. A little bit of patience and /rui seems to be enough for most problems. There are some addons on curse and on the official forums.The community is mostly mature and helpful. Don't hesitate to ask for help in /zone chat.The Lore is very interesting, there's an official comic on FFs site.I suggest this game to anyone who wants to enjoy some action in good company but can't invest too much time.

(But it is fairly interesting because of the setting.)-Armies don't have much for customization. (Ranks, Permissions, Etc. I do suppose they may be working on this but for now it'll stay in the cons.)-Is computer intensive at times.-Graphics glitch out when using ALT + TAB. (Best to run in windowed if you plan to multitask otherwise everything will turn black.)-Interface needs some work. (Primarily more options to customize. (Can't resize/move Minimap, or the Main Bar.)

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 5, 2014
												Very good, fun game. I've heard a lot of criticism about it, and frankly, I don't see it. Here are some of the major problems people have with the game.1. Transportation is only available after level 25 - While true, what you have to realise is that that is level 25 on one class. There are a total of 16 classes, meaning that level 25 is relatively early in the game. In addition, I've only been playing Firefall for 36 hours, at this point, and I have leveled one class to level 23, another to 15, and the other three basic ones to 6/7. So, it doesn't actually take that long to progress anyway.2. Pay to win - This is absolutely not true. Because of the way the currency system works, you can convert in-game currency to Red Beans, which is the paid-for currency. Therefore, it is possible to earn any item you want just by playing the game. Yes, it will take time and effort, but the alternative is for everything to simply be given to the player, negating all semblance of progression. Not to mention the fact that most of the things that you buy with Red Beans are vanity items anyway.3. No variations on weapons - I put this claim down to people not playing the game long enough. While yes, each class has only one type of weapon that they can use, they do vary somewhat. For example, the Assault's weapon is a plasma cannon, with an alt-fire of a shotgun-style blast. Around level 18 or so, I found blueprints for a version that spits fire instead - it keeps the feel of the Assault's weapon, but with a slightly different twist. In addition, I am now level 23 on the Assault, and I haven't found a replacement, so it's definitely paid off.4. No variation on abilities - This is basically the same problem as the above, but I didn't want to write too much in one section. I've heard some people complain that at level 8 (when you unlock your 4th ability), you don't get anything new. This is far from the case. You unlock new abilities at level 15 and 23, which means that you will need to switch out abilities and try new things. The amount of levelling between these abilities is such that it gives you a chance to try the new abilities and playstyles, without letting the game stagnate too much.These are the 4 things I've found to be the most common 'downsides' to the game, and personally, I don't think they stand up. My belief is that people who complain about this game do not understand what the game is about. Firefall is *not* a normal FPS. It is a MMO, first and foremost, which is why I do not understand why people complaining about having to work for their rewards. I do not claim to know everything about MMOs, but Firefall doesn't feel particularly grindy to me. Personally, I think people judge Firefall as an FPS first, when it is an MMO. The majority of people that I have seen bad reviews from have judged the game around level 8-12, without giving the game a chance to show it's diversity.Obviously, this game will not be everyone's favourite, but it is for me. Also, for people who say that the game has become worse since beta, I played this game during beta, and it was too complicated for my taste. Firefall is currently in a much more enjoyable state.

content:
, 2016
Product received for free
												I...I've always wanted this game to be good, the cinematic trailers, the hype, and you played the game for the first time in closed beta, you thought to yourself man this game world is amazing, you can fly around, you can explore everywhere if you try hard enough. The only thing limiting you to seeing more of this world is the giant purple wall of melding.  Back in beta this melding is what controlled server populations as well as explorable game world. It'd slowly creep closer and closer if players couldnt hold back the hordes of chosen, and then that server instance would eventually die to the melding.  This was the game i was introduced to. this beautiful world to explore and see and ignore all the player gameplay because "hey its still beta they are still tweaking things, who cares if voice acting and model animations are incredibly robotic, combat is repatative unless you play assault, range means nothing when quests have scripted ambushes so theres no real reason to play the recon advanced classes.  engineer classes have this weird dinner plate thing with lack luster weapon models and lack luster weapons that could easily just be tertiary weapons.  I dont even use the Tesla, i have my engineers using two secondary weapons (an assault rifle and the RPG) because the tesla is just flat out lame.  Maybe if it had a cone of effect or somthing that didnt just make it a shiny looking assault rifle.  But again, tangents. All these tangents are the built up frustrations of one player,  Red 5 has kept looking at the big stuff, new maps, new monsters. but they have constantly overlooked the little details that really flush out a game.  the bones are there but it has no muscle.  Combat in general is pretty boring unless you are fighting random mobs out in the world, because then you can use your own combat playstyle to the best of your ability (but assault is pretty much the best combat experience in the game currently), Game models are great looking normally, but some animations are just...unnatural.  quests are still served best cold and alone, with no one acknoledging them.  then theres the fortress system, it wouldve been somthing like Wildstar's, but we don't know if they even remember talking about it.basically, we are all waiting for a bigger company to buy the game and use it as a quick cash bull, maybe revitalise the game world as we grit our teeth through never ending grind of producer run gaming industry.

content:
18, 2014
												A really really good concept, but really really poorly executed. There are a few hours of enjoyment to be gained from the starting missions, but when the world opens up, the game just drops off.For starters, the world is waaaaaaay too big. I'd understand the size were it bursting with content, but only tiny little pockets of the world are inhabited. The gap between the quests and quest  hubs is another huge turn-off. How am I supposed to be excited about doing quests when I've had to walk 20 minutes to get to the indicator, killed 10 enemies, and and still have to slog through another 20-minute walk to turn it in. Transportation is another real problem. The game expects you to bear with its grind for 25 levels for you to aquire transportation. Cash store items and temporary vehicles exist, but cash store costs cash, and the temp vehicles are so few and far between that no matter when you use it, it feels like a waste.On a positive note, the vehicles(s9?) feel pretty darn good, and are the only area that this game has gotten right.Looking at this game from a shooter standpoint, you call tell by both combat and visual appearance that this game wants quite badly to be borderlands. However, it manages neither the appearance, nor the feel of its role model. Looking at it from an mmo standpoint, it is standard FTP faire. In fact, if you peel away the claptrap mask, it is literally every boring grind of a freemmo out there.  The quests are stale and repetiive. "Gather X x's" "kill X x's" "walk to X". There's really not too much to keep players around after drawing them in. I imagine that only longterm players of friends of the devs would drop money into this game. After all, the only motivation we have to spend cash is to save time (buying a vehicle), which could just as easily be accoplished by uninstalling the game. So, no, don't play it, unless you're really into grinding or quite bored.Either way, it's free, so the only thing you have to lose is your time.

												In short: Customize your frames, craft your own weapons and burn arachnas.+ 10 points for jetpacks, controls are very intuitive and fun.Been playing this for almost 3 years. Perfect for casual play. There's some grind as in any game of this kind but the difference is FF's grind is not mindless.The world is dynamic, events pop around all the time, there's always something to do and the devs are pumping more content regularly.It has bugs, and the servers are wonky occasionally. A little bit of patience and /rui seems to be enough for most problems. There are some addons on curse and on the official forums.The community is mostly mature and helpful. Don't hesitate to ask for help in /zone chat.The Lore is very interesting, there's an official comic on FFs site.I suggest this game to anyone who wants to enjoy some action in good company but can't invest too much time.

content:
11, 2014
												The game is fun for some hours at the beginning but once you've done a couple of missions, jobs, and things like that the game gets incredibly repetitive. In order to unlock missions (that's basically the story of the game) you have to reach a certain level, and in order to level up you of course need xp, and the only way to get it is either a couple of side events, jobs or thumping, and that's it. The jobs get extremely repetitive, it always sends you LONG distances to the waypoint, and once you reach the waypoint there's little to no things to do, you either kill things, defend something by killing waves of things or it's an escort mission where you have to travel a whole kilometer and defend the person you're escorting to a certain waypoint by killing things. And there is little enemy variety. Once you're done with 1 objective you get another, take a guess what you need to do in the next objective... That's right! Kill things that are miles away. Once you reach level 25 you get a LGV ( motorbike ) recipe which helps you get to places faster, but that doesn't solve the problem that for EVERY SINGLE JOB you need to kill things AND NOTHING ELSE. In the game there are about 4-5 classes and each class branches about in about 2-3 different styles of the class, for example you have the basic Recon class with a mid-long range assault rifle, and the class branches out to a recon class with a long range bolt action rifle ( Nighthawk ) but in order to unlock a different class apart from the basics you need to max out any class to level 40 which as you may have guessed already, takes a craplot of grindingMy final verdict for the game would be 4/10

number of helpful: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
11, 2014
												So, another free MMO is on the market and why should you even try this one?You can view Firefall as a bledn of Planetside 2, Borderlands and a bit of Global Agenda.As such its a lot more of a shooter than your basic MMO, which if you like shooters is REALLY GOOD!Althow it is an MMO it doesnt feel like it, it feels like you're actualy playing your standard co-op game.And it mostly does that through the excellent voice acted missions that you get through a Job board.Now, the missions may not always include you doing something very different every time, but the game makes you care about what you are doing. Are you helping a mother find her son? Are you helping some civilans getting food?The game atleast says what you're doing and that can instantaniously makes you care. And the voice acted bits aren't shoved down your throat like in The old Republic, they are just some messages that you recive and they dont hinder your gameplay.But unlike in the old Republic, your character is silent and doesn't talk at all (they do even joke about it).But let us talk more about the combat. As i said, the game feels more of a co-op game, and even in combat that is clearly visible. Your main source of dispercing damage is your GUN! That means that combat is more Borderlands-esk and even the enemy variety is closely similar to that of Borderlands. But you also have 4 abilities, 3 that you use and have a cool down and the forth ability charges through combat.But besides your regular missions Firefall is also structured to have a more dynamic feel to it. You will find your fellow players gathering resources and some side-mission, which you can ither start yourself or help your fellow soldiers in the field.The gathering of the resources is especialy fun, since it is more of a team oriented thing and you and your friends are besacly just mowing down bugs and enemys as they come coming towards you.There is also a crafting sistem, which works like your usuall crafting sistem with some twists (i have never seen a lot of the crafting sistems in other MMOs). Firstly you need to research what you want to make, and then actualy make it. Fearly basic, but the hard part is actualy juggeling your resources/money.I have mixed feeling on the business model. The devs sure need to make money and i belive they might have actualy been able to get a functioning sistem into their game that is not really pay to win. In game, you can buy red bean coins with real money, that in turn allow you to buy special items from the Red Bean store. Most of these items are luxurious, like a bike (you can make one yourself for free to) and some other cosmetic items. The only problem i have is that the giant gameplay changing item, the one that allows you to play different classes (battleframes) is (for me) kinda costly, since you can pay 10€ just for another run in the game with some different abilities. But its not as bad as it sounds right now. You can actualy earn those Red Bean coins ingame, for free! You can excange your basic money, to credits (which are used for the marketplace) and then those into Red Bean coins. Sure the excange isn't exactly linear, but you can earn the Bean coins without spendint a dime. How ever, the time it takes you to aquire even an usable amount of Bean coins, so it is still very harsh, but hey, you can speed things up with spending money and supporting the devs.In short, Firefall is in my opinion one of the finest MMOs and if you liked Borderlands, Planetside 2 or Global Agenda, you should give this one a look. The begining few levels might be boring, but after you get into the game a bit it just takes off and unlike some MMOs that have you just spaming some abilities you can actualy have tons of fun here!

content:
er 4, 2015
												Firefall is one of my favorite MMOs.  If you like the feel of an open world environment (like most MMOs) and like third or first person shooters I recommend you give Firefall a try.My fav features:Movement.  Just getting around in the game is very fun.  Motorcycles, gliders, jump pads and personal jetpacks!Dynamic quest system.  Repeating a quest does NOT mean you will go to the same location(s).Open world content.  Imagine you are fighting some aliens for a quest and more (aliens, bandits, critters, etc) show up unexpectedly, due to random public content/events.  Time to react or die.  You have to think on your feet and be aware of your surroundings.Crafted gear is useful!  A large percentage of the gear I use was crafted by my character.One character, multiple battleframes (classes).  This means that your inventory and crafting is tied to your character, NOT your class.  So your battleframes level independently, but that cool level 20 submachine gun of doom you crafted for your main battleframe is usable by the battleframe you have reserved for playing with your group of friends (once you get that battleframe to lvl 20)Free to play which means it should be easy to get your friends to try it.You can buy things with actual money, but it's just cosmetic, quality of life, and fun items.  NO Pay to Win.It's very common to be knocked down and have a complete stranger come by to revive you.Playing with a group is fun.What I don't like:Software bugs.  Not a ton, but they are there.  Note:  vendor support is responsive.Lot's of good changes coming in an update soon (maybe in January).  Check out this video for a summary (and some laughs):  video link

content:
7, 2014
												Fun open world MMOFPS. Beautiful environments, great graphics, fun gameplay. Couldn't ask for more from a game. Especially a free one. If you played in beta absolutely give this game another chance, I understand that most games don't change very drastically from beta to launch, but this game is the exception. When I played in closed beta there was basically no content. You started out crafting and thats all you did the entire time. Guard your thumper. They've changed it COMPLETELY. They've added dynamic events constantly goin on in the open world, a massive open world PvP map, tons and tons of quests and probably a ton of stuff I don't even know about. It takes a lot to impress me these days when it comes to MMO's but Firefall has definitely done it.

												FireFallPros:Free To Play - If you dislike it onyl took the length of time to install and playNot "P2W" - You dont need to pay to win at this gameGrind - If you dont pay, you have to work hard to earn you acheviementsAcheivements - There are alot of different acheviements and not one person has them allUpdates - Constantly updated with a in built bug reporterContent - There is lots of Content with World events that change location along with end game content when yoy hit lvl40Socail - Easy to play with others and incouraged to in End Game ContentIn-Game Community - Everyone is generally nice and will help if they canCons:Replayability - Very Repetitive and leveling all frames from 1 - 40 can be boring at timesDifficulty - Some parts of the game are difficult to get around or understandSolo Play - Can be hard to play through soloPVP - Only real PVP is lvl40 content. content:
, 2015
												Fighting for Thump Dump, for almost half an hour. Bonding together with over 40 players to try and stop an overwhelming invasion, more and more enemy reinforcements showing up while we barely manage to contain  the heavy cannons from firing. And just about 2 minutes before the onslaught ends, they break through and destroy the SIN connection. commander shouting "Get the hell outa there we have Melding incoming", as a Blue wall of Death approaches what's left of our squadron. Turn around and boost for are lives , and the sounds of the game stop. It's just the beaten defenders, fleeing in a hail of bullets.Never has a defeat felt so awesome. We were beaten for the day, but some of us would live to fight another. Comrades falling left and right, with no time to save them. And yet we knew we would come back for payback. it was absolutely beautiful.

												As a game developer, this is the perfect story of what not to do to your game. Back in beta, the only complaints anyone had were I want more content and bug fixes, and just look at it now. They removed content, changed the style of the entire game twice, changed the focus several times, spent funding on promoting the hell out of a game nobody wanted to play anymore and sytematically fired all the original staff. At one point this game had remarkable, shining reviews. At the time of writing this, it's 30% Positive! Who knows the ultimate fate of Firefall? It's hard to hear, but I believe it's dead. Fortunately a spiritual successor to this game how it was intended to be, back when it was my favorite game, is already under way. Find it here: http://crixa.io/emberthegame/

content:
y 2
												I was a open/closed beta test player for this a lot of years ago, and it was interesting, fun, and demanded a lot of your time. (Cant Recall which, Never checked the profile for a long time.) When you ventured outskirts, there were generators that were able to expand the zone from the death zone BUT temporarily. It demanded teamwork and patience to move about, but also intense because you couldnt stay in a zone for a long time. Mining was profitable on those places as well but when that timer hits zero, you better haul ♥♥♥ back to the main area. Hell, there were defense events that get everyone SCREWED OVER when that deadly globe expands fast to the location or town you were trying to protect.  That I remember truly. It was intense as I constantly did that with a few more people. I loved that immersion.After a few years of that, on my absence I came back yet again, but the normal version. It was weird, It changed its mainframe system so something about Skill points and Gears. That was odd. I played a few more but stuck on the first major locale since I was just bored and wasting time, doing Tower re-takes, missions and you name it. Then I took a break again and decided to check again. R&D was screwed. You cant use them since they were broken. I noticed a few trying use Thumpers to mine, but since that was broken, What would BE THE MEANING OF R&D? Its just a waste of space on invetory and a system that was good to invest in.I did a few missions and said "Eh." but never gave me that same taste again. I wonder if it's just wore me out or I'm not into this sort of thing, but If I wasnt, I wouldnt participate and play that early. I'm really sorry for something such fun to play solo and with friends, became rather down, I'm sure other's reviews can explain better than I am.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ry 14, 2015
												Note: Steam achievements are rather annoying, unlocked several achievements at once due to being a previous player before steam version came out (only after one achievement was unlocked that i did not have and then all achievements previously unlocked have unlocked)Been a player since the Closed beta, they have seriously come a long way and some of it is not for the better of the game...They have revamped the resources almost 4 different times in the game, changed up the Crafting three seperate times, changed up leveling the frames twice, and changed PVP/PVE functions about twice as well (PVP more than PVE).The game is heavily based around skill of the player with a hint of luck with the gear related, so long as you keep moving you generally will survive most conflicts against the Chosen and the creatures of the world. There is a very diverse variaty of Weapons and Frames to choose from ranging from the classic Archtypes as followsAssault: General class has abilities that can be both used for close combat and long range, your basic build types but branches out into some more exclusive types for Heavier damage or crowd controlDreadnaught: Heavy Class, your massive brick wall that can just take everything and everyone at once and still keep on going, has rapid fire weapons and shield type abilities, branches off into classes that can create shields, become walking armories, or just straight up bullet spitter.Recon: Long range support type class, does have some close combat capabilities but eventually branches out into a long range support class that can be utterly devistating to anything, can cloak itself with certain abilities and even create havoc against the enemy targets by making them attack clones or other enemy troops. Branches off into Heavier sniper type frames armed with Bolt action rifles or charged energy riflesMedic: Healer class, starts off very slow and rather hard to level unless you have some friends but after a while it can branch off to become a very self sufficient frame. Can revive faster than any other class and has abilities to poison and even set some traps if players know what they are doing. Branches off to become a strong healing frame or a more offensive DPS frameEngineer: The Supporter class, can create anything and everything that has a gun attached to it really, can create support turrets, landmines, knockback weapons, and stations that give ammo/health/armor and boosters for damage. Can branch off into a stronger defensive class with more turrets and supportive drops, or an offensive buffer that can boost friendlies weapons and use a railgun.Overall there are quite a few combinations in the end, the game is fun and players who have been around enjoy it and oddly enough still come back to see what else is new with the game...8.5 out of 10

content:
1, 2014
												At least this game is free-to-play. Otherwise I would have wasted some good money.Okay, so it's TRIED to be individual, and to "fix" things that are wrong with MMOs. Well, trying is fine in alpha and such, but now? It just doesn't cut it. Upon first entering the game, you enter a tutorial to teach you about the game's basics. That's all well and good, and tutorials aren't meant to be absolutely amazing and show the game at its best, but they should show you a taster of the game and encourage you to indulge more time into it. However, this isn't the case. Graphics are poor, textures are just splotchy and undefined. This is slightly less on your gun, but even so, the background and scenery is not fantastic. Looking past this, I endevour to listen to the awkward narration informing me about the classes. Slightly generic classes, yet they look fun to play, especially the one called "Assault" where you have a rifle and jetpack-thing. The jetpack proved to be the only fun part.You're thrown into some shooting and you need to defend certain locations from enemies, which is standard for tutorial, and I accepted it. So I was shooting away, along with various other people, and the first thing I noticed was that there was no satisfaction for me. I was shooting these aliens or whatever, and they gave no response. The only thing you notice is their helath dereasing, but then you're not sure whether it's you doing that, or other players. There's no change when shot, they just keep coming at you until they're dead. Now that's a fantastic part of all shooters, the satisfaction of eliminating your targets in the game, and receiving a reaction, whereas you may not be able to do the same thing "irl".So this, along with other reasons, discouraged me and drained the fun out of the experience. The tutorial kind of sucked. Which made me not want to play any more of the game. Well I tried to play more, but upon finishing the tutorial and loading up the next mission, the game crashed and shut down. Zero motivation to load it up again, zero motivation to play it again.Try it, as it's free and might be your cup of tea, but I wasnt satisfied with FireFall.

3, 2014
												This game failed to keep me interested. The initial story cutscene was alright, but after that I was thrust into a world where I had no idea what I was doing. Mind, I was using a controller... but any other shooter game where I've connected a controller, console or otherwise, the controls have all been the same. Firefall completely changed the majority of those controls, and I had no idea what I was doing half the time.On top of that, I didn't even need to do anything. In the first mission, I was just standing at the spawn point trying to figure out the options menu while everyone else murdered all the NPC enemies. I closed the options menu when I heard that the first objective had been cleared, because I wanted to actually contribute. But I felt like I wasn't; there were no less than 20 people shooting with me, so it felt like anything I was doing was pointless.Yes, this is a biased review because I played Destiny just a couple of weeks ago. I'm buying Destiny and deleting Firefall. I would suggest the same for everyone else.

content:
er 26, 2014
												The game itself is great. There are pretty nice encounters and dungeons with fine voice acting that i liked. Bosses are fun to kill and PvP is also enjoyable.. Shooting MMO is something kinda new and this one is from the better ones... BUT... The loot policy in this game is TOTALY wrong. Imagine 10 hours raid in WoW with nothing but green drops. Yes, thats Firefall. They try to slow down players progression that much, that is unacceptable. The fact that shooting game isn't for relaxing (like WoW mainly is), it makes raiding more fun, but you also feel more tired after an hour raid for example... And if you find totaly nothing (No DKP / token system) from that raid.. i really mean NOTHING.. you are pretty disappointed and you feel like you wasted your hour. Every single patch they do follows this loot policy... like a week ago they added a new patch with new dungeon. It was fun to play, again.. i enjoyed it. The dungeon run took me around 40 minutes with other players and guess what i got from the last boss as only reward? Green item. Thats it, 40 minutes wasted, i don't want to do that again.Raid timers reset at wednesday, people usually login just to do time-locked raids (where you have like 10% to get 1 purple item, which is the biggest chance you get in this game) but today, there was like 10 people wanting to raid in the whole EU server. After the last patch, where devs promised "changes to loot system" but players still got screwed, most of them just left the game...The game is dead, no playerbase and im leaving too. Great game killed by series of bad decisions and horrible loot system.

content:

												I´ve been playing this game quite a few month now, since I bought a founder pack in the very beginnig. And I must say its the best MMO in a long time. Even so they changed alot in the process and you gotta start over a couple of times, I´m quite satisfied with the state its in right now.Its rare in any MMO for having so much opportunities. All the Battleframes for example. Even if you dont wanna spend any money on the game you got 5 frames to start with and once you leveld em up you can unlock even more frames.And if you get bored by one frame (which doesnt happen if you choose the right one for you), you can just switch to another frame.You got alot of quests, missions, weapons, skills, areas and pvp just to name a few things.The game takes quite some time to explore and find all the features in the game, but seriously who wants to finish an MMO in one week? :)You dont even have to spend money to level up faster, coz with a group you´re allways leveling up no matter if you got the xp boost or not.All the new missions are fun too and the worldmap is alot bigger then in the beginning. The game isnt as complex anymore with all the diffrent resources gone, which some people like and some hate, but its easier to understand if you´re new to the game.So all in all the game is awesome and was definitely worth the 100$ for the founders pack and I´m spending another 100$ for the Digital Deluxe Edition coz in my opinion I had alot of fun in this game and will have in the future:)Try it out, if you like it support the game^^

29, 2016
												To summarize what's written below: Developers are working on porting this game to other platforms and I would strongly suggest to wait until it is done. With the way the game looks now I think the game will shut down before that happens.So my experience with this game is a little mixed. I tried this game when it first launched for a few days and I thought it was good. There were lots of players, monsters and random battle events (I didn't know why they were taking place, but they were fun). I didn't play it at the time because at the time I had 6 other games on the queue and I got pulled in by 1 of them. Now  I came back to try it and it changed a bit in terms of gameplay (not a bad change in my eyes), but it degraded significantly as an MMO: Some stuff got removed/disabled. I don't want to list it all, but take my word for it: It was there and now it's not. Few bugs (minor bugs; most of the time gameplay doesn't suffer) At least low to mid level areas are empty: No players and almost no events. I feel like I'm running in an empty map most of the time. Developers are working on porting this game to PS4 and "mobile" platforms. To me that means that until the PS4 (and other) versions are made the game will be frozen and playerbase will keep decreasing.

												I have spent a decent amount of time in the Firefall universe and from that I can say Firefall is a great game thats addictive for a long period of time. There is no need to use real life money, most of the items you can buy are cosmetic, vehicles and advanced frames(classes). Once you hit level 40 you can purchase an advanced battleframe for free. The more max levels you have you get a 10% exp increase that stacks for your battleframes that arent level 40. Sadly the late game isn't really that good yet so you will end up doing repetitive level grinding with different battleframes. Over all I would give Firefall 7/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ry 13
												Used to be an excellent, fast-paced MMOFPS. But as time has gone on, most of the enjoyable elements have been stripped out and replaced with extremely simplified and bland systems, while the fast pace has been slowed to a crawl (Most likely to facilitate the paid-purchase Vehicles and Gliders). Performance and stability has gotten progressively worse as well.Some examples of what to expect from modern Firefall:-Lengthy cooldowns on all abilities and usable items. Previously, abilities could be given deployment charges, so that they could be used multiple times before recharge. This is gone.-Alt Fires have been removed from all weapons in favour of Iron Sights. Including the flamethrower. A Flamethrower. With Iron Sights.-Buildings sometimes fail to load entirely after a death and respawn. Previously an extremely rare issue, now more frequent.

ry 10, 2015
												Firefall is the action MMO that I have been looking for.  It has the skill-based shooter action that satisfies my trigger finger, along with the adventure of exploring a vast open world that keeps things from getting boring.  There is always something going on somewhere to help out with, whether you are on a specific job or just wandering around.  By the way, compared with some of the other depressing post-apocalyptic worlds that I have played in games like Defiance, the Firefall world is actually pretty.  I'd be playing it right now, if it wasn't installing a big update!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
, 2015
												Okay, so this is a rough one for me. I've been TRYING to figure out how to write a short review for this game for quite some time, and I think I've got it figured out.This game has come MILES from where it started in some good ways (like simplifying gear / crafting), and in some bad ways (like simplifying gear / crafting). Let me explain that briefly: There used to be a BAJILLION resources, seriously look it up, and it was completely silly. They managed to trim it down to base resources, and it was certainly (unless you have some form of crazy you agree) a vast improvement. The problem is, this game with a complete dumbing down of the gear system. You used to be able to deeply customize your frames (jump jets - armor - energy - speed) all kinds of stuff, and it was pretty cool (though a bit rough to keep up with in crafting). The new version basically lets you equip a "core" that modifies energy, jumping, etc. and then lets you equip ability modules, and guns, that's it. I know, I know, it's way more simple, but in a strange way, it also killed some of the MMO feeling to the game.The story is ... well ... there now, which is another huge step up. The voice-over missions are a nice touch, and the expanded zones hare pretty sweet as well (though it's a bit sparse in terms of content).Now, for people that don't give a crap about what the game used to be in contrast, here's the quick and dirty list:GOOD:The game is easy on the eyes, has character for days, controls are tight, combat is fun, guns feel good, kills are gratifying (even after your millionth one).BAD:Getting around sucks, which means you are going to buy a vehicle from the cash shop rather you want to or not (unless something has changed in my off time in which case I'll edit this), Thumping for resources doesn't feel as meaningful as it should, crafting is a bit shallow, no reason for alts / re-rolls at all (possibly a good feature), world (though huge) still doesn't feel very fleshed out, and it's oddly demanding on system resources for a fairly old game (poor optimization).Should you play it?Yeah, sure, why the hell not? As a FTP title, it's fine. Install it, run through a few hours, worst case scenario you don't like it, and you uninstall it. If you have a few buddies to play the game with, it's a pretty good time (I don't much care for it solo but maybe that's more your bag). There you have it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
1, 2014
												Firefall is a great MMORPG for it being Free to Play. Unlike most F2Ps, it doesn't act like a Pay to Win, rather Pay for convenience and cosmetics. It has an excellent crafting system, but it takes a while for the items to be completed. You can, however, pay 1 Red Bean, which is the game's paid currency, to instantly complete the crafting process. You aren't required to pay for Red Beans, however. With using the game's common currency, Crystite, you can obtain Credits, and convert those credits into Red Beans. You can obtain nearly everything in this game without spending anything, which I would like to see in more games. I didn't think this game would've changed much from the Beta, but it turns out that this game finally made it's way out of development hell. Replayable missions, great combat mechanics, fun dynamic events, good loot system, beautiful open-world, this game is really good and I think people should at least try it as it is Free to Play.

content:
29, 2016
												To summarize what's written below: Developers are working on porting this game to other platforms and I would strongly suggest to wait until it is done. With the way the game looks now I think the game will shut down before that happens.So my experience with this game is a little mixed. I tried this game when it first launched for a few days and I thought it was good. There were lots of players, monsters and random battle events (I didn't know why they were taking place, but they were fun). I didn't play it at the time because at the time I had 6 other games on the queue and I got pulled in by 1 of them. Now  I came back to try it and it changed a bit in terms of gameplay (not a bad change in my eyes), but it degraded significantly as an MMO: Some stuff got removed/disabled. I don't want to list it all, but take my word for it: It was there and now it's not. Few bugs (minor bugs; most of the time gameplay doesn't suffer) At least low to mid level areas are empty: No players and almost no events. I feel like I'm running in an empty map most of the time. Developers are working on porting this game to PS4 and "mobile" platforms. To me that means that until the PS4 (and other) versions are made the game will be frozen and playerbase will keep decreasing.

												I played this when it was first playable, about 2yrs ago or something and it wasn't fun... but it was in Alpha.I played it today and was very IMPRESSED.  I've been playing MMOs for about 10yrs and Firefall reminds me of one of my favorites, Global Agenda.  I'm tired of tab-targeting like in WoW and SWTOR.  I now prefer games like World of Tanks and Naval Action where you have to aim.  Firefall does that as well.  Graphics are good, if you like the Borderland look. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
, 2015
												I'm giving this game a qualified recommendation (read full review for clarification) that could just as well be a not recommended rating given how you look at my review.The game as it exists now is pretty good and you're not likely to find any other MMORPG shooter that has character build diversity in the form of Battle Frames instead of classes that this one has.  There was a lack of content at launch for the Americas and Europe but they've added a lot of content since then.  As a free to play game I can safely recommend it but I should note several caveats in doing so.This is really still a game in beta development at this point despite the fact that it was launched as finished product in the Americas and Europe.  This is pretty much undeniable as they have already gone through several small iterations of changes in core game mechanics such as the perk system, the module system used to customize player gear, an overhaul of the crafting system and changes in group loot distribution mechanics.The real launch is probably going to be the launch of the game in China at which point they are going to implement a gigantic block of changes that are going to substantively change core game mechanics such as weapon characteristics such as rate of fire, recoil and unique characteristics for some such as overheating for the Plasma Canon for the Assault Battle Frames, removal of a core aspect of the modules (power rating which scales damage up), and a complete redesign of the crafting system, scaling of mob damage and many other things.What this means is that the game you are going to be playing if you choose to play this game now instead of waiting until the end of the year will not be what the game is going to be with the China launch.  That also means that your gear will most likely be devalued with those changes which some players may want to avoid because that is a significant loss of investment of a player's time.  There has already been mention of item migration (the exchange of current in game items for new ones) for the crafting system but historically item migration in this game has meant inventory nerf.Therefore while I can recommend the game to play as a free to play game, I cannot recommend you invest any actual money in this game until there is a clear vision of what the game is after the China launch and, if you believe you would be frustrated seeing all or many of the fruits of your in game labor getting nerfed, I would advise you to hold off playing the game until then as well.One final note, the state of PvP in this game is pretty bad and probably as low as you're likely to find in any game.  The PvP comprises of duels and open world pvp in a region called Broken Peninsula, but the open world PvP has been shut down by the devs as a failure even though players can still engage in PvP there without the rewards system.  Arena PvP is going to be part of the China release version but currently no one has any idea what that will be like.

content:
r 19, 2016
												I haven't played this game in a while, but I think I should say, that I played when it was in Beta, when everything was simple. It was what WoW/GW/GW2 had to offer, but syfy, simple to get a grasp of, AND f2p. But I had noticed that when I did play this again, that everything was a bit more difficult to understand, and get the grasp of.  I noticed, if you were a vet and had higher rigs (Even beginning rigs) for the most part, combat was easy. I remeber the Choosen normally was taking watch towers left and right. Players had to constantly take them back; and taking them back wasn't all that easy. But when I played I could basically 1 man take a tower back with engineer.And for it being easy, almost all the events(Bosses, raids,etc.) were extremely easy to complete, you only had a bunch of people there to just get some quick and easy loot. But when I started playing this in 2014, everything about it was a bit challengeing and I think thats what most people liked, was that it wasn't easy to do everything, then that one patch came or something and then anyone; Experienced, or new could be able to 1 man any event or enemy. So, I wouldn't reccomend this game to anyone, if it was back when it was in beta I would've def reccomended this to anyone who asked about this, but now I don't think anyone should play this game till they do something about it and try to bring it back to the way it was back in beta.

You can, however, pay 1 Red Bean, which is the game's paid currency, to instantly complete the crafting process. You aren't required to pay for Red Beans, however. With using the game's common currency, Crystite, you can obtain Credits, and convert those credits into Red Beans. You can obtain nearly everything in this game without spending anything, which I would like to see in more games. I didn't think this game would've changed much from the Beta, but it turns out that this game finally made it's way out of development hell. Replayable missions, great combat mechanics, fun dynamic events, good loot system, beautiful open-world, this game is really good and I think people should at least try it as it is Free to Play.

content:
ber 1, 2014
												This game is alright, I enjoy it. There are great things about it. You can have multiple classes and switch at any civilized area. You have the jump packs, and the Gliders which allow for long distance "flying". There are Bikes, Mining (Thumping), and you can do it all in a Squad with your friends. It's also truly Free to Play. You don;t need to spend any real money unless you want to be a VIP player. Or you devote hours are quests and convert what you get into Red Beans (VIP currency). I wouldn't recommend doing that though, my friend spent several hours trying to get enough stuff and only got 28 Red Beans which is practically nothing.There are issues I have with it. There's VERY little campaign, as in you get a campaign mission every few levels. The missions are pretty straight forward, you go somewhere, shoot some people, and then go back to where you started. I also believe the game was supposed to be originally PvP, but I've only seen that in some much higher level areas. Which brings up another problem: the maps, while very large, are few. There are around 6 different maps (I can't remeber I can't bother to check).The game has potenial to be something great, its just not there yet. You could play it, you could not, but I've enjoyed it somefar. Though I admit, playing alone is boring as Hell.
